editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,363 texts created during Phase 1 of the project have been released into the public domain as of 1 January 2015. Anyone can now take and use these texts for their own purposes, but we respectfully request that due credit and attribution is given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Amorous Widow: OR, THE WANTON WIFE. A COMEDY. As it is Perform'd by Her MAJESTY'S Servants.
Written by the late Famous Mr. THOMAS BETTERTON.
Now firſt Printed from the Original Copy.

list.label: SIR Peter Pride. A great Boaſter of his Honour, his Valour, what a noble Family he is deriv'd from, and of their mighty Courage.
Cuningham. A Gentleman in love with Philadelphia, and is much courted by the Widow.
Lovemore. His Friend, in love with Mr. Brittle's Wife, and endeavours to have an Intrigue with her; but the Widow courts him too.
Barnaby Brittle. An old Citizen that keeps a Glaſsſhop, marry'd to Sir Peter Pride's Daughter.
Jeffrey. Servant to Cuningham, in love with Prudence.
Clodpole. A ſimple Country Fellow that Lovemore employs in ſending Letters to Mrs. Brittle.
Merryman. A Falconer to Cuningham, who takes upon him to repreſent the Viſcount Sans-Terre, that is to marry the Widow.
Lady Laycock. An amorous old Widow, that courts every one ſhe can for Marriage, ſancying her ſelf ſo engaging, that all that ſee her muſt love her.
Lady Pride. Wife to Sir Peter, a formal old Lady that boaſts much of her Gentility, and of her great Name and Family.
Mrs. Brittle. Their Daughter, Wife to Barnaby Brittle; a Cunning, Intrieguing Coquet, that always over-reaches her Husband.
Philadelphia. Niece to the Widow, in love with Cuningham.
Prudence. Maid to the Widow.
Damaris. Maid to Mrs. Brittle, that aſſiſts her in her Intriegues.

body.head: THE Amorous Widow: OR, THE WANTON WIFE.

div.head: ACT I. SCENE a Room.
div.stage: Enter Philadelphia with a Letter, follow'd by Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I Should believe Mr. Cuningham very conſtant, if I had Faith enough to credit this Letter, Jeffry. What Complaints are here? But 'tis the Stile, that all young Lovers write.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, believe me; you know I am a Man of Integrity: I cannot diſſemble. Let him write what he pleaſes, If he did not love you, do you think I'd tell you ſo?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: When he has Opportunity, I muſt confeſs, he ſays kind things to me.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Take my Word, Madam, my Maſter is not like other Men—Unleſs he loves a Lady, and loves her paſſionately too, he never troubles himſelf to compliment her much.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Never? Yes, Jeffry; ſometimes, you know, he compliments my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: That's a convincing Proof of his Love to you; you cannot think him reduc'd to the Neceſſity of making Love to an antiquated Piece, with deſign to know her otherwiſe, than to obtain the Happineſs of ſeeing you? But I ſhall tell him, Madam—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Tell him I have receiv'd and read his Letter.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Is that all, Madam?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: All! Yes. Are you not content with that?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Any indifferent Perſon, that had Hands, and could but read, would have done, as much, as that.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well; Tell him then, in time perhaps I may—

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: My Maſter, Madam, can't endure to depend on a perhaps.

div.stage: Enter Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Quick, quick, up to your Chamber, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What's the Matter? Is my Aunt coming hither?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: She's at your Heels. Go up the Back-Stairs quickly.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Farewel, Jeffry; Commend me to thy Maſter. Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: For what, I beſeech you? Is not my Maſter bewitc'd, to court a Lady a whole Year, and ſhe hardly tell him ſhe loves him yet?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Alas! She's but a Novice. Let me alone with her; I'll order the Buſineſs ſo, that if thy Maſter be diſcreet and paſſionate enough in his Expreſſions, he wins her Heart I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: He can ſay nothing to her, but that damn'd Aunt of hers is harkning to't ſtill. What Pleaſure can ſhe find in Love at Fifty?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Fie, Jeffry, you muſt ſay Five and twenty.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I wonder any Woman can have the Impudence to live, and trouble Mankind after that Age.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: There never was a Woman ſo old, but ſhe retain'd a good Opinion of her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Then ſhe dreſſes her ſelf ſo fantaſtically, that all may ſee ſhe ſtrives to appear Young in defiance of Nature. She is more gawdy in that ſhe calls Half-Mourning, than a young Bride is on her Wedding-Night. The Devil's in her if ſhe believes any one can love her: 'Tis jeering her, but to be commonly civil to her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A little Flattery fires her. She believes all, that is ſaid to her: And he that does not make love to her, and compliment her, ſhall not be twice admitted to her Houſe.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: O reverend Beauty! on my Conſcience, if I would greaſe her Chops with a few Compliments, ſhe'd mump and ſmile upon me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: When ſhall my Maſter have an Opportunity to ſpeak freely to Philadelphia?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore is thy Maſter's Friend, and is better belov'd here, than he imagines You muſt perſuade him to amuſe the Aunt, that Mr. Cuningham may have Convenience to court the Niece.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore's tir'd with playing that part ſo often; he is cloy'd with the Aunt, and ſwears he'll have no more of her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'm ſure her Niece and I endure much more. Tell him, 'twill be Charity in him to relieve us.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: 'Twill be hard to perſuade him to it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: This old Lady of mine has languiſh'd for a young Husband ever ſince Sir Oliver Laycock dy'd: She cares not what Eſtate he has, or what Religion he's of, ſo he be but young and luſty. Where is the great Viſcount Sans Terre, thy Maſter told her of? Methinks he's long a coming.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Some croſs unlucky Buſineſs hinders him.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: She has lately receiv'd ſome Letters, that have given a full Account of him.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: So much the worſe. What is it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: They ſay his Fortune is not very much, but he is greatly born, and very pleaſant; and that he is ſo great a Lover of Muſick, he has not a Servant but can Sing or Dance, or Play upon ſome Inſtrument. You may know when he's come by the Noiſe; the Fiddlers will welcome him to Town; for all from Weſtminſter to Wapping pay him Homage.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Wou'd he were but marry'd to her, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Whether he marries her or not, is not our Buſineſs, Jeffry. Let him but fool with us till thy Maſter has gain'd her Niece, and then our Work is done.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Well, we have had enough of thy old Lady Laycock. Let us now talk of our own Affairs; ſpeak, doſt thou love me, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A pleaſant Queſtion! Do you doubt it now?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: If you would have me credit you, ſwear it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Sure you are jealous Jeffry?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: You're ſomewhat near the Matter. I know your Humour well enough; you love a bold audacious Fellow, that will ſay any thing, and ſuch a one we have come to Town, one Merryman our Falconer; I fear you'll like him better than you do me.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh Fool! why ſhould you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I have ſome Honour in me; but he's a Fellow that has eaten Shame, and drank after it. He is more impudent than a Court Page, and will take no Denial.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, here's my Lady.

div.stage: Enter Lady Laycock.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What Buſineſs has Jeffry with you?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: His Maſter ſent him to know, whether he might have leave to wait upon your Ladyſhip this Morning.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes; Tell him, I expect him.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: He durſt not come, becauſe Mr. Lovemore's with him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go tell 'em, if they pleaſe to come, they ſhall be welcome both.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I ſhall, Madam. (Exit Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You ſee what Power your Beauty has. Neither can live a Moment without ſeeing you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, they have other Buſineſs with me, Prudence; they came from Paris lately, and brought me a Letter from my Brother; and I believe they come for my Anſwer now.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But does not one of 'em love you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have ſome Reaſon to believe he does; Mr. Lovemore has ſpar'd no Pains to perſuade me to quit my Widow-hood.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I have been told, Madam, that Widow-hood is a Gift, Heaven ſeldom beſtows but on its Favourites; you are rich, and know how troubleſome Marriage is. For my part, I believe the faireſt Hair, the beautiful'ſt Curls do not become your Fore-head ſo well as Bando did; but every one, Madam, knows their own Neceſſities.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I confeſs, Widow-hood has its Conveniencies; but if Marriage be a Trouble to ſome, 'tis a Pleaſure to others, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You had the Experience of it thirty Years, how did you like it, Madam? They ſay, Sir Oliver Laycock lov'd your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For all that he was jealous; and, what's worſe, was Old.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Very well; therefore you reſolve to have a young One now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You cannot blame me for that? Can you, Prudence?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh no, 'tis well known Youth is comfortable. But, methinks, you ſhould take one a little nearer your own Age, Madam. A very young Man may be too treacherous for you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why, is my Age ſo viſible?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: No, Madam; with a little Help of Art you have ſome Remains of Beauty ſtill. You have ſomething about your Eyes as pleaſant now, as others have at Twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis a very malicious World we live in, Prudence; they are ſo apt to cenſure, and ſpeak of any ſingle Woman, that one ought to marry to avoid that Scandal.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Some that are young are forc'd to marry, to avoid Detraction; others wou'd rather all that's Ill ſhould be ſaid of them, than to have no Notice taken of 'em. I knew a young Lady that pin'd to a Conſumption, becauſe ſhe liv'd three Years about the Court, and never had the Honour to be lampoon'd. The Truth is, none that are Beautiful and Young can avoid Envy, but few are ſo malicious, to ſpeak againſt the Old.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There is no Age exempt from Scandal, Prudence. When we are Young, they ſay we ſell our ſelves; when Old, we are forc'd to hire, to buy our Lovers.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: You know what they ſay, Madam, of the old Marchioneſs, your Friend, that was ſo admir'd, ſo courted in her Youth; who, when ſhe found ſhe was forſook by all, was forc'd to hire a Player by the Quarter: How ſoon rhe poor Fellow was tir'd too! How like a Sheep-biter he look'd after the firſt two Months!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This London is a very wicked Place, 'tis impoſſible to live without Scandal here.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'm afraid they'll ſay as much of you, Madam, if you bargain for a Husband. To covet one, that is both Young and Rich, is too much in Conſcience, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Thou know'ſt, Prudence, Wealth is not the thing I ſeek.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Then, Madam, the Buſineſs is done; the Viſcount Sans-Terre ſhall be your Husband, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah Prudence! if he were but as handſome as—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Ah Madam, that's too much.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why may not I wiſh for it?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Conſider his Quality, Madam, and 'bate him ſomething for that. One thing I muſt adviſe you; be not too prodigal of your Gold at firſt; to be liberal ſometimes will be convenient, and make him kinder to you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For all this, I ſhould think my ſelf very happy, if I were certain of Mr. Cuningham or Mr. Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A little Jealouſy will inflame 'em. They'll be more preſſing when the Viſcount comes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But yet methinks, Cuningham and my Neice—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Are always whiſpering.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He only compliments her, Madam. She's too young to make Love ſeriouſly.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: With your Favour, there's no truſting to that. To my Knowledge, there are thoſe younger, than ſhe, that underſtand what Love is but too well.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: That's true, Madam; but Philadelphia is ſo innocent, that no Man can make Love to her, but to divert himſelf. Here ſhe is, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What does ſhe come for? I'll ſend her packing quickly.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Conſider what you do, Madam. How can Mr. Lovemore entertain your Ladyſhip, unleſs his Friend may divert himſelf the while with rallying with your Niece.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: For all that I could wiſh—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Pray trouble not your ſelf. Truſt me, I'll watch her, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Will your Ladyſhip go to Eaton's? The Coach is at the Door.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, I'll not go yet.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If you ſtay long, Madam, the beſt Poynt will be ſold before you come.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No matter. Ha! what ails the Girl! How ſtrangely ſhe looks! Her Eyes are hardly open yet!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: How, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Then her Head's dreſs'd awry. How it diſguiſes her! Lord! how frightfully it looks!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Truly, Aunt, 'tis dreſs'd juſt as the Faſhion is.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Fetch her Hood, Prudence; I'll have her put it on till it be mended.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I dreſs'd it to pleaſe no body but my ſelf, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll have you dreſs your ſelf now to pleaſe me: Come, put it on.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My Lady's in the Right. Never was any thing more ridiculous. Here, put on the Hood, I am ſure this is much handſomer.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Why don't you put it on?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I can't endure it, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: So; Now it is as it ſhould be; all modeſt Maids ſhould be dreſs'd ſo: But here's Mr. Cuningham and Mr. Lovemore.

div.stage: Enter Cuningham, Lovemore and Jeffry.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Servant, Madam; you ſee how we love your Company, by giving you this Trouble in a Morning.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis a Happineſs we are much envy'd for.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You are welcome, Gentlemen. Pray command this Houſe as freely as your own.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why does this Lady hide her Face? Pray, Madam, let us ſee you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Forbear, Sir, I beſeech you: She has had the Tooth-Ach lately. If ſhe takes off her Hood, ſhe'll catch cold, and bring the Pain again.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I thank your Ladyſhip for your Care of me. But the Pain has been gone ſo long, I don't fear it now.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay then, we muſt have it off.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: What ſay you, Madam, Shall I pull it off?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, Impertinence; I ſee you have a Mind to ſhew your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Tis the Nature of all young Girls to do what they are forbidden.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I come not to trouble your Ladyſhip for your Letter to my Lawyer; your countenancing my Buſineſs will be of great Advantage to me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: This, Sir, is what my Brother commands me: You ſhall ſee I take delight to ſerve his Friends.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, You promis'd me that Honourable Title.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you pretend to it?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, more, than any one.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have not much Beauty to boaſt of; but Virtue, Sir, makes ſome amends for the Defects of the other.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Defects? (Cuningham Courts Philadelphia. Pray, Madam, wrong not your ſelf ſo much.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: There are few but know a little their own Value: And tho a Woman be not fam'd for a great Beauty, yet if ſhe be agreeable, there are thoſe, will like her well enough.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You have that in Perfection, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: In that, Sir, I know you do not flater.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Then, Madam, you like my Choice of this Suit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Extremely well: Was it your own Fancy, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I am not aſham'd to own it, ſince you ask it, Madam.

div.stage: [They counterfeit to be talking about Faſhions, whilſt ſeemingly Lovemore Courts the Aunt.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'll liſten to 'em—
He talks to her of nothing but new Faſhions. [To the Widow. You may, Madam, venture to diſcourſe without diſturbance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, tell me freely; how old do you think I am?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, if you were not a Widow, I ſhould think you a Girl ſcarce Twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Now, Sir, you flater me: You might have ſaid Thirty. I do not love to diſguiſe my Age.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How! Thirty, Madam! and look ſo youthful: I'll not believe it, 'tis impoſſible!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You do not know what Miſery I endur'd whilſt my old Husband liv'd. The Griefs I had upon me would have diſtracted another Woman. Alas! Sir, 'tis not Age but Sorrow has broke me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It makes me ſad to hear you tell it, Madam, and vexes me to think, an old Man ſhould enjoy ſuch Happineſs.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You do not know how many Tears I have ſhed.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis ſome Comfort, Madam, to remember he did not live long with you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, Fifteen Years.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Yes, and Fifteen to that. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Having been ſo unfortunate in a Husband, you may believe I have but little Encouragement to venture, Sir, again. For I am very happy now I am alone.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You do wiſely, Madam; for ſhe deſerves not to be pity'd, that raſhly runs into the ſame Misfortune; and therefore you have, Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I have not forſworn Marrying yet.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, where do you uſe to walk in the Evening? Into St. James's Park?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Not very often, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Or into the Mulberry Garden?
Is not the Wilderneſs very pleaſant?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If I like my Company, Sir, I never miſlike the Place.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Have you ſeen the new Paradiſe, Madam? 'Tis much ſuperiour to the former.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I have heard as much: But, Sir—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Let me have the Honour to wait upon you thither preſently.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Not yet, Sir; After Dinner, if you pleaſe. But tell me, Sir, do you think me ſuch an Enemy to Marriage, that were I ſure a young Gentleman lov'd
me, and lov'd me truly, I would be ſo uncivil to refuſe him?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: When I conſider what you endur'd in Sir Oliver Laycock's time, I think you ought to do it, Madam; and that Man's unjuſt, that urges you to break your Reſolution.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray do not miſtake me, Sir; I have made no ſuch Reſolution yet.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Nay, Madam, ſince you are diſpleas'd at what I ſaid, we'll change the Diſcourſe. Pray, Madam, do you think the young Lord Lucky has that Intereſt at Court, that Fame reports he has?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Lord, Sir, this is a ſtrange wild Anſwer to my Queſtion. Let me tell you, Sir, if I have any Merit, Wealth or Beauty, there's one in the World deſerves 'em all.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Good! How ſhe teazes him! (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: But has that one no Fault, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You know him very well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I know him, Madam!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Yes, you, Sir. 'Tis your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! What will become of me now?

div.stage: Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What now?

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: The Marchioneſs is come to viſit you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Troubleſome Creature. Go one of you and entertain her quickly.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Which of us, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go you, Philadelphia, and keep her Company till I come.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I ſhall, Madam. (Exit Phil.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what is this Marchioneſs?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p:
Oh, Sir! a moſt eternal Talker: Her Tongue goes like the Larum of a Clock, as faſt, and to the
ſame Tune ſtill. She's almoſt Sixty, and yet pretends to Beauty, and loves Courtſhip moſt unreaſonably. Say but a kind thing to her, and you win her Heart. The Truth is, ſhe has not much Reputation; but the Reſpect I give her is to her Quality and to her Perſon. But ſhe's an Original in her kind, Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh blind, blind Creature! ſhe draws her own Picture, and laughs at it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Sure, Madam, her Converſation muſt be very pleaſant?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: She has been much courted in her Youth; but 'twould make one die to hear her boaſt of her Lovers now. How this Knight ſighs, and that Lord dies for her; when all the while I know what Neceſſity the poor Creature is reduc'd to. I would have brought her hither, but I know we never ſhould have been rid of her. Excuſe me a Moment, I'll ſend her away, and return preſently. Your Servant, Gentlemen, Exit Lady.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: How now, Friend—What's the Matter? Why doſt look ſo ſullenly?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I play the Aſs here any longer! No; if I do, may I turn Pudding to a Rope-Dancer, and ſhew Tricks next Bartholomew Fair.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Nay, but Friend, Dear Friend—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Tell not me of Friendſhip. What Man would endure to be ſo plagued as I have been. I have parry'd with my beſt Skill the dangerous Thruſts that ever were made at me. To tug at an Oar, or dig in a Mine in Peru, is Recreation to it. But the firſt time to offer Marriage to me! I ſweat to think on it. It made me tremble twice, for fear ſhe ſhould have forc'd my Neck into her muddy Nooſe of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: We have no other way to blind her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis all one to me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If thou lov'ſt my Life, Friend, do not forſake me now.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray live, if you pleaſe, and give me leave to do ſo too. Should I again be left alone with her, the beſt I can hope for is Diſtraction.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: How do you like the Niece?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She's all Perfection.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: How do you thrive? Do you find her kind, Mr. Cuningham?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: She has promis'd me a Meeting this Afternoon, if thou canſt but remove the Aunt from us.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: I'll try what I can do, but Mr. Lovemore is the only Man in her Favour.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Dear Friend, try but this one.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd, drawn, and quarter'd for a Traitor firſt, and have my Limbs hung up for the Birds to feed upon. No, no, I have my Belly full, I thank you, and ſome to ſpare.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But now I think on't, where's this Viſcount all this while? His Arrival wou'd be of great uſe in this Affair.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prudence adviſes well: Methinks he's long a coming.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Why, you muſt know, there is one Merryman juſt come up out of the Country-He is my Falconer upon occaſion, the Fellow is bold, and very apt, and has not been ſeen much in Town. What think you of him to act awhile, till ſome more lucky Occaſion preſent it ſelf?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Tis a lucky Thought, and may be of uſe. Where is he?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: In the Pantry, a ramming down a Wedge of Roaſt-Beef to keep out the Town Air, and making Sport with a ſimple Country Fellow he has brought out of the Country with him to ſee the Town; one Clodpole, he calls him.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Twould not be amiſs to examine him, and inſtruct him how to behave himſelf, before he is too much known.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: No body of the Family has ſeen him▪ yet, but the Butler; and he, I know, will be ſecret.
I'll ſtep and call him to you, Sir, if you pleaſe?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Do ſo. (Exit Jeff.
In the mean time, Prudence, there's ſomething to buy thee a Pair of Gloves. (Gives her Money.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! how long have I deſerved this? Pleaſe to command me any thing within my Power, and conclude it done.

div.stage: Enter Jeffrey with Merryman dreſs'd like a Falconer.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir, I found him juſt paſſing by the Door, and have told him part of the Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Friend, doſt think thou can'ſt act the Part of a Viſcount for a little while?

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: What ſort of a Lord is he to be?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! An Amorous Reſolute ſort of a Perſon, that's much given to love Muſick. You ſhall have all things that's ſitting for a Man of ſuch Quality.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Well, Sir, let me be once ſet out with a good Equipage, and leave the reſt to me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Come with us, Friend, and we'll inſtruct thee fully in thy Part.

sp.speaker: Merr.
sp.p: Well, give me but my Cue of Entrance, and let me alone to act my Part.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Let's about it then. (Exit Lovemore, Cuningham and Merryman.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Prudence—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What's your Will?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: One Kiſs.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Pſhaw! Is that all? (He kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: All! I ſay no more, but—
Ah Prudence, Prudence!

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: What damnable whining Tone haſt thou got, ha?

sp.speaker: Jeff
sp.p: I am afraid of this Viſcount, Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Away, you Fool; I have other things to trouble my Head withal—Farewel.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Adieu. (Exeunt ſeverally.

div.head: ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Cuningham and Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: WHy, Madam, are you ſo unwilling to credit what my conſtant Paſſion, ſo long in vain, has urg'd? Do you not believe I love you? Oh! Did you but know what I endure, when you refuſe to hear me, you would in Charity have ſome Compaſſion on my wounded Soul.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I dare not hear this Language from you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What are you afraid of, Madam?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: All Men ſay the ſame things, Sir, till they have won our eaſy Hearts to pity and believe you; then ſtraight you ſlight your Conqueſt, and leave us to purſue our Ruin.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Be not ſo cruel to cenſure all for thoſe Faults, which ſome few commit; for all, I muſt confeſs, do not ſtand excus'd. But, Madam, you cannot be ſo great a Stranger to my Love, as not to think it real; or ſo great an Enemy to your own Worth, to believe it has not Power to enſlave a Heart, that's guarded more ſecurely than mine—But no more—Your Aunt—

div.stage: Enter Lady Laycock.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: So Niece, I ſee your ſqueamiſh Stomach can digeſt all ſorts of Diet, tho ne'er ſo ſtrictly charg'd to the contrary. Mr. Cuningham, What Buſineſs have you with her? I wonder you are not aſham'd to be always following of her at this rate, and endeavouring to take Advantage of her fooliſh Youth; for ſhe is but a Girl yet, and not fit for the Converſation of a Man, nay, or indeed to be truſted with her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Go, go, indeed you are much to blame▪ What will the World judge, think you? Or what Excuſe can I make, for ſuffering ſuch Doings in my Houſe? And you, Huſwife! how dare you diſobey my Commands? Is this the Reſpect you pay to me, and to my Quality! I believe, in a little time I muſt make it my whole Imploy to invite home young Gallants, forſooth, to pleaſure you, whilſt I, as if I were your Slave, muſt retire, and wait till you are ſerv'd firſt. 'Tis come to a fine paſs indeed; but I'll put an End to it all, and keep you always lock'd up in your Chamber, I will ſo.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I told you▪ Sir, what would be the Event of your Projects, but you would not be ſaid nay. I muſt be an Inſtrument to make your Paſſion known, and none ſo fit to be truſted with ſuch an Affair as I; but henceforward if you can't ſpeak for your ſelf, you may hang or drown, as you pretend, for me, for I'll no more get Anger for you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What does ſhe mean?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What's that you ſay?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mr. Cuningham here, Madam, is always urging me to tell your Ladyſhip the Paſſion he has for you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Saucy Slut!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: As if he could not ſpeak for himſelf, but muſt be ſtill plaguing me, and ſwearing how long, how well, and how tenderly he loves you; then ſighs and cries, Oh Philadelphia! Can I live without her? But ſhe, cruel as ſhe is▪ has vow'd to die unmarried.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh the Devil! What will become of me now?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then raves worſe, than any one in Bedlam, crying, And muſt I then loſe her ſo? Oh! Death to all my Hopes! I muſt not, cannot, will not! and a thouſand ſuch like things, which I'm reſolv'd never to hear again. So, Sir, don't trouble me any more, but e'en ſpeak what you have to ſay to her your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Is this true, Mr. Cuningham? I did not think there was a Man living, which cou'd love at that rate, and with ſuch Conſtancy.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! Madam! what ſhall I ſay, ſince all is ſtill in vain! Your Vow, your cruel Vow, has vanquiſh'd all my Hopes; then where ſhould I ſeek for Peace, but in my laſt Retreat, the Grave. Farewell; I cannot bear to ſtay, for every Look adds new Poiſons to my Soul. (Is going.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Stay, Sir—I have made no ſuch Vow. If your Paſſion—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! forbear. I know your Goodneſs to be ſuch, that rather, than be the Inſtrument of what may happen, you would ſeemingly comply with any thing I can ask. Pardon me, Madam, I have been too much deceiv'd already.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray ſtay, Sir, do not miſtake—

div.stage: Enter Philadelphia with a Piece of Poynt.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, here's the fineſt Piece of Poynt I ever ſaw, and the cheapeſt; pray, Madam, look at it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Saucy Intruſion. How durſt you come without being call'd? How often have I told you this, you Minx: Be gone, and leave it in the next Room, till I pleaſe to come and look on't.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam, the Woman, that brought it is in haſte, ſhe bid me tell your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Let her go about her Buſineſs, if ſhe can't wait, for I'll not come yet. (Exit Philadelphia.
How horribly unlucky was this to diſturb me, juſt as I was going to tell him of my Intentions, and of my Concern for his Paſſion. (A ſide.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I believe I am troubleſome, Madam. (Is going. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No, pray ſtay, Sir, I have ſomething to ſay to you, but that young Slut interrupted me.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh the Devil!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But as I was going to ſay, I did indeed reſolve not to marry any more; and when you have heard me out, you'll ſay I had Reaſon.

You muſt know, in my Husband Sir Oliver's Days, I had not that Liberty, perhaps, as other Ladies of Quality took; for, to ſay Truth, my airy Temper and my Youth, at that time, made my Husband grows jealous, tho' without Cauſe, Heaven knows.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: That I dare ſwear, if all were of my Mind.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Which made him lead me a very uneaſy Life: So that it made me reſolve on many things at that time, and one was this, That if ever Sir Oliver ſhould die, I never would marry again; but I don't remember that I ſwore to it: Or if I had, you have ſuch a way with you, 'twould be very hard to deny you any thing, Mr. Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, Madam!—Your Charity comes now too late: I am paſt all Hope.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, ſay not ſo! for ſince you ſay your Diſeaſe is grown to that Extremity, that unleſs your Love meet Reward—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Talk not of Impoſſibilities. I know how much you prize your Honour: And ſince you have vow'd never to marry, I have nothing left to hope for elſe.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis true, Mr. Cuningham, I would not have my Honour ſuffer; but what remains beſide that I can do, to ſave you from what may be dangerous, ſhall not be wanting.

div.stage: Enter Prudence and Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! Madam! the rareſt News—The Viſcount Sans Terre, whom you have ſo long expected, is juſt arriv'd, and is coming hither with a huge fine Equipage, Fiddles, and other Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh dear! how I'm ſurpriz'd! I would not have him ſee me thus for all the World. Prudence, Ser my Curls right, and alter my Knots: Quickly, don't ſtand ſumbling—
Look if the Paint be ſirm.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Tis pretty well, Madam; There's here and there a ſmall Crack, but 'twill not be diſcern'd at diſtance.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Quickly, good Prudence: Put me a little better in Order. You'll pardon me, Sir: You ſee what a Fright I'm in.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Pardon, quotha! the Devil take me, if any thing could be more freely granted. (Aſide.

div.stage: Enter the Viſcount Sans Terre, with Muſick, and a good Equipage; attended by Lovemore and ſeveral Gentlemen. The Viſcount ſings as he enters.

lg.head: A CATCH.
lg.l: Where I heard of the Fame
I had paſs'd for an Aſs,
Had I ſtay'd where I was,
And not done a Viſcount's Duty.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Oh! are theſe the Ladies?
By your Favour, Sweet Lady. (Kiſſes Philadelphia.
A delicate Morſel, by this Hand.
Madam, I ſee that Fame has juſtly ſpoke your Praiſe. You are indeed the Wonder of all your Sex.
How fair ſhe is!

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What does he mean?

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what young Gentlewoman is that, whoſe matchleſs Beauty ſeems to ſill the Place with more, than common Brightneſs? Sure 'tis ſome Goddeſs, dropt from Heaven for Men to worſhip!
Fair Angel, pardon this rude Attempt:
The Honour only of your fair Hand. (Kiſſes it.
For till I touch it, I cannot think you mortal.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! You make me bluſh.

sp.speaker: Viſ.
sp.p: [To Phil.] Pray, Lady, is this pretty young Gentlewoman your Niece?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: [Aſide.] This Fellow muſt be a Fool, or he could ne'er miſtake ſo groſly.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: [To Phil.] Now we ſhall have rare Sport. Sure he's blind to miſtake you for your Aunt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: [To Phil.] Pray have a little Patience, Madam, and you'll ſee the Event.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Lady; I bleſs thoſe Stars that have directed me to ſo happy a Choice; therefore few Words are beſt. If you like me as well as I do like you, e'en ſend for a Parſon— To Phil.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, ſure you miſtake!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Now—Now it works. [Aſide to Phil.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: What ſay you, Lady? Shall we— [To Phil.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. [Aſide.
Pray, Sir, are not you the Viſcount Sans Terre?

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Pretty Creature, I am.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And come with an Intention—

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: To make this Lady, your Aunt, happy in a Husband, if ſhe pleaſes.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I tell you, Sir, I am that Lady you ſpeak of; and that is, my Niece Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha; Your Niece, quotha!
Why ſure you think to put ſome Trick upon me.
This motherly grave Lady your Niece!
No, No; I thank you, Madam, I am not to be perſwaded out of my Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: He makes me almoſt mad. (Aſide.
I ſay again, that I am call'd the Lady Laycock;
And that pert Minx my Niece; who was left in Charge with me till ſhe be of Age.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: 'Sdheart, 'tis impoſſible! You look Twenty Years younger than that Lady you call your Niece.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! That indeed may well be: A great many do allow, I appear to be ſomething younger than I altogether am.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: How could I be ſo much miſtaken!
Sure, Madam, you but jeſt with me.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, theſe Gentlemen know I ſpeak Truth.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Tis very true indeed, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Well, ſince it happens ſo, I like it the better; for to ſay Truth, I had fix'd my Eye on you at my firſt Entrance.
Ah! wou'd 'twere over once.
Methinks I long to have thee in my Arms.
Oh! How I would employ my Faculties,
And ſurfeit with delight.
What ſay you, Lady? Never ſtand to conſider on't, but ſend for a Parſon to ſay Grace, that I may fall to. Odds ſo, I'm very hungry—Very ſharp ſet;
I long to be doing.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, walk in, and refreſh your ſelf after your Journey. I was unmannerly not to ask you before.
Prudence, Come hither. See that all things are in readineſs. Oh, Prudence! I am impatient to be alone with him. Exit Pru.
My Lord, you will excuſe the Diſorder you have found me in.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Never trouble your ſelf about it. Join but your Forces with mine, and we'll beget a Race of People, that ſhall be immortal. A Race, that ſhall create a ſecond War with Jove, and raiſe Olympus top equal with the Seat of him, that hurls the Thunder.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: No more, my Lord. Pray walk in.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: All your Commands are abſolute.

div.stage: [Exit Viſcount leading the Widow, who puſhes out Phil.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a Piece of Fly-Fleſh?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: The Rogue acted it to the Life, and came very ſeaſonably to my Reſcue.
Had he ſtaid a Moment longer, I had been forc'd to have given up the Ghoſt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That ever Nature ſhould ſuffer ſuch a Lump of Rubbiſh in the World for Men to ſtumble over.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Pox on her old mouldy Chops:
She's for engroiſing all to her ſelf.
How ſhe thruſt her Niece in before her!
I'll in, and try to beckon her into the Garden, if you'll interpoſe, ſhou'd the Aunt miſs her, and follow us.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! Would'ſt have me run into the Lion's Den, juſt when I have ſcap'd his Paw!
No, I have hazarded too much already to venture more, I thank you. I now have better Game in Chace.
You know pretty Mrs. Brittle, Sir Peter Pride's Daughter?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis the ſweeteſt little Creature!
So Fair, ſo Witty, ſo Kind, and ſo Promiſing!

I'm juſt now ſending this Letter, in order to appoint a Meeting with her. But her Husband is ſo jealous (as indeed I hope to give him Cauſe for't) his Eye is hardly ever off her. I am thinking what way it can be deliver'd without Suſpicion. Let me ſee—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I'll take my Leave; for I find I interrupt your Meditations.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Farewel, my Friend; and may both our Wiſhes proſper. (Exit Cuningham.
Jeffrey.

div.stage: Enter Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Can'ſt thou contrive to carry this Letter to a young Gentlewoman, and bring an Anſwer, without being ſuſpected? If thou doſt, Jeffrey, thou ſhalt be well rewarded for thy Pains.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Is ſhe Widow, Wife, or Maid, pray Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why doſt thou ask?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: For a private Reaſon I have.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well then, to ſatisfy thy Curioſity, Jeffrey, know ſhe's a Wife; a Young, a Handſome, and a Melting one!
I am all Ecſtaſy, and impatient till I poſſeſs her.
Good Jeffrey, look on the Superſcription, and about it with all Speed.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I dare not touch it:
Don't truſt me with it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why ſo, good Jeffrey?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I ſay again, do not truſt me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Reaſon, Jeffrey?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: I don't care to meddle in a Cauſe, where there's a Proceſs of Cuckoldom going forward.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Prithee, why ſo?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Why, Sir, I'll tell you. You muſt know, Sir, I love Prudence, my Lady Laycock's Woman, and I believe there's no Love loſt between us; nor do I know how ſoon we may exchange our Perſons for better and for worſe. Now, Sir, if I ſhould be the Inſtrument (by carrying this Letter) of your making this honeſt Man a Cuckold, who knows but, in return of ſuch a monſtrous Deed, it may be my own Caſe next; therefore, Sir, I don't care to meddle in't.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Give me the Letter again; I did but try thee. Thy Maſter, indeed, has often told me, how ſcrupulous thou wert about theſe Matters, but I ne'er believ'd it till now. Stick to thy Principles, and be what thou deſerv'ſt, thou mayſt come to Good at laſt. I have no farther Service at preſent. Prithee leave me, I have Buſineſs of Moment. (Exit Jeffrey.

I had been finely ſerv'd if I had ſent this conſcientious Rogue. What ſhall I do? The Viſcount brought an ignorant Country Fellow up with him, that won't be ſuſpected in the leaſt. 'Tis well thought of; I'll entruſt him, and ſend it immediately. Soft—Who comes here?—Oh! 'tis the Husband.

div.stage: Enter Barnaby Brittle.
div.p: Your Servant, Mr. Brittle; is the Lady Laycock at home, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I believe ſhe is.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I have a little Buſineſs, and muſt needs ſpeak with her. Sir, your Servant.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: A little Buſineſs, quotha!
A fine Trade this doating old Widow drives; my Houſe is become as common for all Commers and Goers, as the Mall or Spring-Garden: But I ſhall put a ſtop to it in a little time, I believe.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Brittle in haſte, dreſs'd very airy; he ſtops her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How now—Whither away in ſuch haſte?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I'm going abroad, Husband. Good bye.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, by your Leave, I'll know for what, and whither your ſweet Ladyſhip is going?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Why, to the Play, ſweet Husband.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Hum! to the Play.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Good bye, Husband—I ſhall be too late, and then there'll be ſuch crowding, I ſhan't get the firſt Row in the Box, for 'tis a new Play; and I had as lief not go, as ſit behind.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hold, hold, pray ſtay, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed but I can't.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Indeed but you muſt not go, Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed, Husband, but I ſhall.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I ſay again, you muſt not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Muſt not! Who ſhall hinder me?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, that will I.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I ſay, No.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: But I ſay, Yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Don't you pretend to't.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Don't you provoke me, I ſay. Is this the Trade you always intend to drive?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Yes indeed is it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I ſay, No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But I ſay, Yes. Do you think you ſhall keep me always ſtifling within Doors, where there's no body to be ſeen but your old fuſty ſelf? No, I'll to the Play, where there's all ſorts of Company and Diverſion; where the Actors repreſent all the Briskneſs and Gaiety of Life and Pleaſure; where one is entertain'd with airy Beaux, and fine Gallants, which ogle, ſigh, and talk the prettieſt things in the World. Methinks 'tis rare to hear a young brisk Fellow court a handſome young Laſs, and ſhe all the while making ſuch pretty dumb Signs: firſt turns aſide to ſee who obſerves, then ſpreads her Fan before her Face, heaves up her Breaſts, and ſighs—at which he ſtill ſwears he loves her above all the World—and preſſes hard his Suit; tells her, what Force her Beauty, her Wit, her Shape, her Mien, all join'd in one, are of. At which ſhe bluſhing curteſies low, and to her ſelf replies, What charming Words he ſpeaks! his Perſon's Heavenly, and his Voice Divine. By your Leave, Husband, you make me ſtay long.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Not in the leaſt—there will be no great miſs of you, if you don't go. And now you talk of Gallants, bleſs us!—What a Dreſs is there! Do you think that fit for a Tradeſman's Wife?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p:
No;—but I think it fit for Sir Peter Pride's Daughter, ſuch as I am. I warrant you'd have me go abroad like one, thar ſells Butter and Eggs—Or like one that cries, Come buy my dainty fine pickled Cucumbers: No, no, I'm reſolv'd to dreſs—put on all the Airs I can—go
abroad—ſee and be ſeen—take my Fill of Pleaſure, and not be ſhut up in a Nunnery, to pine and ſigh, and waſte my youthful Days in fruitleſs Wiſhes: No, I'm not ſo weary of my Life yet, tho▪ you do all you can to make me ſo. And I would have you to know, tho you have forc'd me to wed my ſelf with old Age and ill Humours, I am not wedded to my Grave!—'tis time enough forty Years hence to think of that, and I have a great deal to do before that time comes; therefore I muſt, and I will go abroad.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Stir one Step if you dare (Spits in his Fiſt. If you go to that, I'll try who wears the Breeches, you or I. You ſhall ſtay at home, and keep me Company; I'll ſpoil your going to Plays, your Appointments, and your Intriegues—I'll make you know, that I am your Husband, and that you ſhall do what I pleaſe. Slife, What's here to do! What, have you forgot your Marriage Vows already? Pray, who am I? Am I not your Husband? Are you not married to me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No—You forc'd me; I never gave you my Conſent in Word or in Deed. Could you think I was in Love with Avarice, with Age and Impotence?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Give me Patience! How! How!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No, you baſely bought me of my Father and Mother.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Would I could ſell thee again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Like a Slave you bought me, and ſo you intend to uſe me, were I Fool enough, but I'll ſee you hang'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, what will your ſweet Ladyſhip do? I bought you, you ſay?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Yes; Had you my Conſent? or did you once ask it? Or if you had, my Affections were plac'd elſewhere, and ſo they ſhall remain.
In ſpight of all your Threats and boaſted Power! I'll not be us'd at this Rate!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I that am a Gentlewoman, deſcended from the worſhipful Family of the Pride's by the Father's ſide—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay, ſo 'tis a ſign by your Dreſs. Pride's, quotha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: And a Gentlewoman deſcended from the Honourable Family of the Laycock's by the Mother's ſide. (She Cries.
And to be us'd at this Rate by an old naſty Shopkeeper!

I might have married a Merchant, and have kept my Glaſs Coach, my tall Footmen in fine Liveries, have gone abroad when I pleas'd without Controul, viſited Quality, nay, took Place of em at the Play-houſe, and met with Reſpect from the beſt; and is it come to this? But I'll to my honourable Father and Mother, and tell 'em all, who, I'm ſure, won't ſuffer their Daughter to be thus abus'd. (Cries ſtill.
I cannot, nor will not endure it any longer. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: This 'tis for a Tradeſman to marry a Gentlewoman. A Curſe on ſuch Gentility! What ſhall I do? I ſhall be damnably plagu'd with her Father and Mother. Well, next Month I muſt take up in Bedlam; a Judgment, which every Citizen deſerves, that marries above his Quality. (Exit.

div.head: ACT III.
div.stage: SCENE, A Street before a Glaſs-Shop.
Enter Brittle Solus.
div.p: WEll! What a Plague 'tis to be married!

I muſt incorporate with one above my Quality too, and not be content with ſomething in my own Sphere, like one that had a Mind to live in Peace and Quietneſs, but nothing would ſerve me but a Gentlewoman, altho I took her with never a Tatter to her Back, forſooth; and now, I think, I'm fitted with a Vengeance. Would I were but fairly rid of her, and her Gentility once, the Devil ſhould take all ſuch Gentility before I'd ever concern my ſelf with it again. But who have we here?
div.stage: Enter Clodpole as out of Brittle's Houſe, looking about him as afraid to be ſeen.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Huſh!—Softly!—Mum—No body ſees—Ha, ha, ha—No body ſees! Softly!—Ods my Life, who's that?—Mum!—Not a Word.— (Is ſtealing off.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Friend, hiſt—Friend—Pray ſtay a little; What Buſineſs might you have in that Houſe?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Wou'd you know now? Softly!—Not a Word. Ha, ha, ha, you underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: But you muſt know—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do know already, but am not ſuch a Fool to tell you. You ſhan't get a Word out of me. You underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, very well, but—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly!—not a Word.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I know that; but who was you to ſpeak with in that Houſe?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly!—Can no body hear? For you muſt know, the old Cuckold of that Houſe, they ſay, is damnably given to be jealous; I would not for ne'er ſo much he ſhould ſee me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You muſt not ſay any thing—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, not a Word.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: His Wife's a main pretty ſmirking Rogue, as a Man would wiſh to lay his Leg o'er.
Softly!—Is no body coming?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I'll warrant thee—Prithee go on.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: What? you want to know all, do you? But I'll not truſt you. Mum! not a Word. You underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I underſtand you well enough—but you may truſt me, I ſhan't ſay a Word.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why luck now!—Ha, ha, ha, Wou'd you, would you? But you ſhall get nothing out of me.
I'll warrant you'd have me tell you now, that I brought a Letter to the Gentlewoman of that Houſe—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hum!

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And that I deliver'd it to none but her ſelf—as I was order'd—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: So.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You underſtand me?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, perfectly well.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And that I ſtay'd for an Anſwer—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, and I hope you got one?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Mum! not a Syllable! no body muſt know!—If it ſhould come to the Knowledge of the Cuckold her Husband, 'twill ſpoil all.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh never fear.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You'll ſay nothing of what I have told you?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, not a Word.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: For you muſt know, Mr. Lovemore charg'd me, when he ſent me, to ſay never a Word.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Is the Gentleman's Name Lovemore, ſay you?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why, do you know him?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, very well; a tall, proper, handſome Man, and always very generous.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: The ſame, the ſame.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And lives juſt—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: At the lower end of this Street on t'other ſide of the way, over againſt the Golden Ball.
I find you do know him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Know him! Why he's my very good Friend.
A Pox of all ſuch Friendſhip. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Odd, he's a fine Gentleman as ever I met with in all my Life.

sp.speaker: Brit.
sp.p: Yes, yes, he's a very fine Gentleman indeed.
I wou'd the Devil had him. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: He gave me this Piece of Gold to carry a Letter for him, which I deliver'd to the Gentlewoman of that Houſe but now.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, he's a very civil Gentleman; I have been long acquainted with him.
Well, and what Anſwer did you get
A very pleaſing one, I'll warrant you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly, you muſt not tell a Syllable of this to the Husband, nor that ſhe'll ſend my Maſter an Anſwer, as ſoon as ever ſhe can get the Cuckold out of the way. But no body muſt know. You underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, I'll keep your Counſel, never fear.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: She bad me tell him, ſhe'd meet him this Evening, if ſhe can.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And that ſhe's very ſenſibly ob—ob—obliged to him, for his Kindneſs to her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay, no doubt on't.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And takes it mighty kind of him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: She does.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Odd, ſhe's a pretty Bit; and then there's a handſome Maid that waits upon her, and is Aſſiſtant to her in theſe Matters, one Dam—Damaris, I think they call her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay, like enough.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: And you muſt know I like her hugely. She gave me Two or Three ſuch loving Looks, that I am half perſuaded ſhe likes me. So that if my Maſter gets acquainted with the Miſtreſs, I intend to ſtrike in with her Maid.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, all but Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: But no body muſt know of it.
You underſtand me.
Well, good bye to you. My Maſter will wonder I ſtay ſo long. Be ſure you ſay nothing now.
You underſtand me. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I do ſo; farewel.
Well, Barnaby Brittle, now thou ſee'ſt what comes of marrying of a Gentlewoman. I believe thou wilt be married to ſomething elſe in a little time, if thou art not ſo already. (Points to his Head.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter Pride and Lady Pride.

sp.speaker: Sir Pet.
sp.p: You ſeem diſorder'd, Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And I have Reaſon to be ſo, if ever any Man had. (Walks to and fro in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Good lack! And why ſo ſhort, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I ſhall grow taller in a little time, Good Mother-in-law, if this Trade holds. (Points to his Head.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Explain your Meaning, Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: 'Twill explain it ſelf ſhortly. (Walks up and down.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: What, is that Hat of yours nail'd on? Do you know who we are? And the Reſpect due to Perſons of our Quality, good Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! wou'd I did not; but now I know to my Sorrow, ſince you will have me ſpeak, good Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Will you never leave that ſaucy Word, of calling me Mother-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good Lord! Why what muſt I call you then?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You ought to ſay, Madam and Sir, when you ſpeak to us; or when you ſpeak of us, you ſhould ſay, Sir Peter, and her Ladyſhip: For tho' you have married our Daughter, yet there is a great deal of diſtinction betwixt you and Perſons of our Rank and Quality.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Go to, it is enough for me to let him know his Duty, without your Inſtructions. Sure, I beſt know my ſelf what to do. Son-in-law, you are an impudent Fellow to uſe us at this rate. How often muſt we put you in mind of your Duty and Reſpect, e'er you'll know it? Hence-forward learn to behave your ſelf as you ought, or you ſhall hear on't in other ſort of Terms. You muſt not think becauſe you've married our Daughter, that we will be ſatisfied with ſuch indifferent Ceremonies and Duty you might have paid, had you married one equal with your ſelf; nor ought you indeed to ſay, your Wife, when you ſpeak of our Daughter.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack!—Is not your Daughter my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: She is.—But you ought not to call her ſo.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I know that too well, now 'tis too late. I'd give a thouſand Pounds ſhe were not my Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: At it again? I tell you, tho' you have married her, yet as ſhe is our Daughter, you muſt not treat her after that familiar way.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: You make me mad—Is not my Wife my Wife?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I tell you, tho' ſhe be your Wife, you muſt not call her ſo. When you ſpeak of her, as being our Daughter, you muſt ſay, Madam.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, then ſince it muſt be Madam, I did not care if ſhe were a Dutcheſs, ſo I were but fairly rid of her.

Here's ſuch a ſtir about your Gentility, and your Honour: But I believe if I had not married your Daughter, and with my good Money redeem'd your Eſtate, your Gentility had been left in the Mud—for all your great Families, and your nice Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Then do you think it no Honour to be ally'd to the Worſhipful Family of the Pride's.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: And to the Honourable Family of the Laycock's? Go, Clown. 'Tis a Shame our Daughter ſhould be wedded to ſuch a Brute. We have been told at what a rate you treat her. What is the Reaſon of it, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, you ſhall know, good Mother-in-law.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Again at that affronting way!
How often have you been told to ſay, Madam?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, then: I always forget theſe fine Words. But, Madam, if you wou'd pleaſe, Madam, to hear me ſpeak, you ſhall know, Madam, whether I have not Cauſe to wiſh, I never had ſeen my Wi—your Daughter, Madam, if I muſt call her nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Well, Sir, proceed.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, in the firſt Place, I am in a fair way to be made a Cuckold, if I am not one already.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: How, Son-in-law? Have a Care what you ſay.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Believe me, what I ſay, I can make appear.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Do it then preſently.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, ſhe has juſt now receiv'd a Letter from her Gallant, and made an Appointment to meet him this Evening; and judge how ſmall a time a Pair of Horns are a grafting.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: How came you to know this, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, juſt now—I caught the Fellow, that brought her the Letter, coming out of my Houſe, and not knowing who I was, I got out of him all the Buſineſs; and that his Maſter, Mr. Lovemore—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Is that the Gentleman's Name?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, ſo his Man told me. I have often ſeen him taking a View about my Houſe, and looking up to the Windows; and 'tis plain what his Deſigns were.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: If this be true, I'll tear her Eyes out.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Nay, if it be, this good Sword (never yet drawn in vain) ſhall do you Right.
Where is ſhe, Son-in-law.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Within, I'll warrant, ſtudying what Excuſe to make, to get abroad, and meet her Gallant.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: I'll call her to anſwer for her ſelf.
Be ſure you wrong her not, Son-in-law. (Exit Lady.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Nay, nay, I make no doubt but ſhe is to be believ'd before me; and ſhe ne'er wants Cunning to bring her ſelf off, I'll ſay that for her, tho' the Caſe be ne'er ſo plain.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: By this good Light, if ſhe dares be falſe to her Marriage Vows, ſhe dies; and that baſe Rifler of her Fame ſhall bear her Company.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh! Here he comes; that Spoiler of my Honour; that's he.

div.stage: Enter Lovemore. Sir Peter meets him. They ſtare each other i'th' Face.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Do you know who I am, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I don't well remember I ever had much Acquaintance with you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I am call'd Sir Peter Pride.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: It may be ſo: I've heard of you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: My Family, Sir, has ſtood theſe many Years with unblemiſh'd Fame and Honour.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very likely, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: How far you have endeavour'd to ſtain that ſpotleſs Fame, be judge your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, explain this Riddle.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I have a Daughter young, fair, well-bred, has Senſe; ſhe is indeed the Wonder of her Sex, and this Man, whom you ſee here, has the Honour to be married to her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! 'Tis an Honour, that I cou'd have ſpar'd.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Now, Sir, I'm told, that you endeavour to corrupt her Honour, and defile her Marriage-Bed. Sir, I have had the Honour to command abroad, and with Succeſs, both to my King and my Country—As have alſo the Chief Part of all our great Race; even from William the Conqueror, to this preſent Reign, have our unqueſtion'd Glories ſtood a Pattern to our yet riſing Fame: And he who dares preſume to rob us of that precious Jewel, Honour, muſt not think to ſcape unpuniſh'd, tho' with the Hazard o'th' laſt Drop of Blood, that is leſt, to waſh off the Stain. My Daughter's Honour, Sir, is as dear to me, as this vital Air, by which I breath and live.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pray Sir, who told you this?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, whate'er I ſay, I can quote my Author for it.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then who-ever told you is a Raſcal; and were he here, I'd ram the Lie down his Throat, or make him eat a Piece of my Sword.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Why he told me—This Man—Her Husband here juſtified it to my Face, and ſaid he had Proof.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: How, Sir! Did you frame this abominable Falſhood? 'Tis well you have the Honour to be ally'd to this worthy Knight, Sir Peter Pride, here; or you ſhould know what it is to father ſuch a Lie upon a Man of my Reputation.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Oh! Here comes my Daughter.

div.stage: Enter Lady Pride, Mrs. Brittle, and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Did you, Madam, tell your Husband a ſtrange Story, that I ſhould make Love to you, and endeavour'd to corrupt your Honour?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I tell him! Why, when did you make Love to me, Sir? I aſſure you, had you let me know of your Paſſion, it ſhou'd not have gone unrewarded. Pray, next time you ſend, let it be one that knows how to take more Care. However, you have no great Reaſon to deſpair; for ſince he complains without any manner of Reaſon, I am reſolv'd he ſhall have Cauſe. Therefore if you do love me, Sir, pray let me know it, and I do aſſure you, you ſhall not want Encouragement. He ſhall not uſe me at this rate for nothing.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, believe me, 'tis all a Riddle to me; for, till this Hour, I never heard any thing mention'd like it: I am an abſolute Stranger to it.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you hear that, you Clown? Are you not aſham'd to abuſe a Gentlewoman continually, without any Cauſe?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What is the Meaning of this, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Pray, do but hear me.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Troth, Son-in-law, you are a very impudent Fellow.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hear me but ſpeak?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: You ſhall not ſpeak.
We have heard too much already.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I am ſure Damaris knows, I never have any body comes near me, but ſuch as himſelf; nor ever receiv'd any Meſſage, either by Letter, or otherwiſe—

I never committed any Crime againſt him, that I know of, unleſs ſitting by my ſelf all Day, and poring over two or three good Books be an Offence. Speak, Damaris, did I ever give him any Cauſe for theſe Suſpicions, and this Uſage? Thou know'ſt all I ſay or do.

sp.speaker: Damaris.
sp.p: Madam, I know no Reaſon; nor can I bear to ſee the Hardſhip you endure! Like a barbarous Man as he is—To abuſe ſo good a Lady! ſo Virtuous, ſo Innocent, and ſo Pious a Lady! I am ſure it makes me weep to think on't—I am afraid he'll break her Heart in a little time, if—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hold your Tongue, you Jade, or I'll make you feel my double Fiſt. You are not a Gentlewoman—
I may do what I pleaſe with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Father! (Cries.
I am not able to endure this any longer.
Never was any Woman abus'd as I am.
I beg you will do me Juſtice, for I can bear it no longer. (Exit crying.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Damaris, let's follow her, and endeavour to comfort her. Oh, thou Clown, to uſe a Gentlewoman with ſo much Cruelty!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I fear he'll be the Death of her at one time or another. (Exeunt Lady Pride and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What do you think of all this, Sir?
Are not you a very pretty Fellow?
Come hither, Son-in-law, ask this Gentleman Pardon, for the Affront you have put upon him in belying of him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How! ask his Pardon, that would have made me a Cuckold?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sir Peter, pray—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I ſay no more Words: He has wrong'd a Gentleman; and the leaſt he can do, is begging Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: 'Tis very well! He offends, and I muſt ask Pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No matter for that, you hear he denies it; and 'tis enough, if a Gentleman unſays what he has ſaid.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: So that if I catch him making me a Cuckold, and he denies it, I muſt not believe it, becauſe a Gentleman ſaid it.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I ſay, you ſhall ask Pardon: Therefore no more Words, but do't.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I ſhall run mad.
Well, what muſt I do?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Come hither: Take your Hat off— Kneel down, and ſay after me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, ſince it muſt be ſo— (Kneels.
This 'tis to be marry'd to a Gentlewoman, forſooth.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir, I ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Sir, I ask your Pardon. (In the ſame Tone▪

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: For the Affront I have put upon you.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: For the Affront I have put upon you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: By falſly accuſing you—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How! falſely accuſing him!

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I ſay no more Words. Say after me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Say after me.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Accuſing you, of having a Deſign to corrupt my Wife's Honour.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Accuſing you of Truth—And having a Deſign to corrupt my Wife's Honour.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: For which, knowing my ſelf in the wrong, I do ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: For which, knowing my ſelf not in the wrong, I'm forc'd to ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Sir, upon Sir Peter Pride's Account▪ I am content to paſs it by this time: But let me hear no more Complaints. (Brittle riſes, and runs off.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Sir, now all is well, I humbly take my Leave. (Exit Sir Peter.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Was there ever ſuch a lucky Rogue as I? For her to encourage me to make Love to her before her Husband's Face!
Nay, and before her Father and Mother too!
Oh, I am all on Fire till I have her in my Arms!
But ſoft! who comes here?

div.stage: Enter Prudence.
div.p: Well, my little Scout, what News? How fares my Friend? Is Philadelphia kind? Where's thy Lady?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Where▪e'er her Perſon is, I'm ſure her beſt Thoughts are ſtill employ'd on you. And however ſhe may pretend a Paſſion for Mr. Cuningham, ſhe loves none but you. Pray, Sir, do but try her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh racking Thought! I'd rather make Love to a Convocation of Cats at a Witch's Up-ſitting, than but ſpeak to her. Where's my Friend? Oh! here he comes, and his fair Conſort.

div.stage: Enter Cuningham and Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Be not ſo cruel to ſay, you want the Power: If we neglect this Opportunity, which kindly preſents it ſelf, the next perhaps may not be ours.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Would you then have me diſpoſe of my ſelf without my Aunt's Conſent? Do not urge me to that, ſince I have promiſed not to wed without it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I ask not her Conſent, but yours: Grant me but that, and leave the reſt to Time and Chance.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, how can you deny him that, ſince I know you love him?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ha! Oh, the charming Sound!
And will you not conſent to make me happy?
Or do you not believe I love you?
By all thoſe Fires that burn within my Soul, I ſwear—

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Hold! Hold, Sir! You have ſworn enough already to corrupt a whole Nunnery of Sighing, Praying and Wiſhing young Votaries. Why don't you give him your Hand, ſince he has your Heart. I believe you love to hear him ſwear and—Give him your Hand, or, I'll diſcover all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Well, there 'tis then; (Gives her Hand to Cuningham.
But I promiſe nothing elſe. I fear I have given too much already.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, never! never! I'll pay thee back ſo vaſt a ſtore of Love and Conſtancy, as ſhall weary thee with ſtill receiving.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, Madam, your Aunt's behind you.

div.stage: Enter Widow.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! My Aunt! What ſhall I do?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam, but give me your Hand.
I'll bring all off. (Pretends to tell her Fortune▪

This Line ſeems to Point out ſome unexpected Croſs: And this Line thwarting the Line of Life, ſignifies a retir'd Life; and this joining with it, ſhews you'll be in Danger of ending the latter part of your Days in a Nunnery. (Widow behind them.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How, Mr. Cuningham! Can you tell Fortunes?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I underſtand a little Palmiſtry, Madam, and can give a Gheſs at Phyſiognomy.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: 'Tis very well.

When I enter'd firſt, I thought you had been making
Love to my Neice: I am glad to find it otherwiſe. But where's the Viſcount?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: In the next Room, Madam.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll wait upon him: I'd feign try whether his Inſide be anſwerable to his outward Appearance.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Nay, prithee ſtay; I can aſſure you, he is not to be equall'd either in Perſon or Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He is indeed a fine proper Man, as one would wiſh to ſee.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why, really his Lordſhip has Parts.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You and Prudence go find him out, and bear him Company awhile; I'll wait on him immediately, tell him. You, Sir, may go with 'em, if you pleaſe. (To Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, moſt willingly.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Sdeath! You won't leave me? (Aſide to Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, but I will; doſt think I'll ſtay to endure a ſecond Hell? For if there be one upon Earth, 'tis being left alone with her.
Madam, Your Ladyſhip ſhall ever command me. (To the Widow.
Come, Lady, if you pleaſe, the Honour of your fair Hand. (To Phil.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What will become of me now? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Cuningham, I have long'd for ſome time to be alone with you, that I might ſpeak more freely to you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, 'tis too great an Honour.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I wonder, Sir, you never think of Marrying?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, as yet I dare not think on't.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! Pray, why ſo?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Becauſe I have not well conſider'd it; and I have been told, 'tis a dangerous Undertaking, without having well thought before-hand.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, why ſhould you think ſo?
I'll vow 'tis an odd Thought, Sir, for one of your Underſtanding: Why, Sir, I'll tell you.

I have had Three Husbands, and yet I have no great Reaſon to complain: Tho' in my laſt Husband's time, I had not altogether that real Satisfaction, as I had with the other Two; for to deal freely with you, Sir, my Husband Sir Oliver Laycock, though he was a very well-bred Man, yet he had his Humours ſometimes, and would be a little given to Jealouſy, ſo that I ſeldom led a quiet Hour when the Fit was upon him. But in my firſt Husband's Days, ſure never Woman liv'd ſo happy! I would not a-been unmarried to have had all the Riches of the Earth laid at my Feet: But when I married with Sir Oliver, and had once ſeen his Temper, nothing I had in the World but what I would a given to a been free again; and indeed in my Paſſion I often vow'd never (if pleaſe Heav'n Sir Oliver died) to marry any more.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: 'Twas raſhly done.

But no doubt, were there that Man fitting to merit your Favour, and equally deſerving your Perſon and your Eſtate, and one whom your Ladyſhip could like, you might perhaps be perſuaded to break your Vow, and venture once again.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll ſwear I hardly think it, and yet one don't know how one may be tempted; tho' if I were to be perſuaded, (and I will not forſwear any thing) I know not any one, that can ſo ſoon perſuade me to it as you, Mr. Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Death and the Devil! What have I brought upon my ſelf! (Aſide.
Oh Madam! You make me bluſh.
But Madam! How cou'd you with Honour put off the Viſcount, who you know loves you, and is come on purpoſe to marry you?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Why, I intend him for my Niece you muſt know, who no doubt will be much better pleas'd with the Change. For, to ſay Truth, Mr. Cuningham, I have always had more, than a common Eſteem for you, and for your Behaviour; and have long ſince reſolv'd, that if I do alter my Condition, you are the Man alone I have plac'd my Thoughts upon.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: You make me bluſh, Madam.
Wou'd I were a League under-ground, or in any Hell but this. (Aſide.
You cannot ſure. (To her.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: I vow 'tis true, and yet—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Hear me but ſpeak, Madam?

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: 'Tis odd, that Love ſhou'd over-power People at ſo ſtrange a rate.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: But I ſhould be unjuſt to my Friend, who I know loves you dearer, than his Life.

sp.speaker: Wid.
sp.p: Oh dear! Who's that I beſeech you, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Mr. Lovemore! I'll ſwear I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh Madam! 'tis but too true, as will appear I'm afraid, when he knows you place your Affections on any other Man.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll vow you much ſurprize me, Mr. Cuningham; but how came you to know it?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oft has he begg'd me to bear him Company in ſome lonely Place, where he wou'd ſigh, and tell ſuch things of his diſtreſſed Paſſion, as wou'd have mov'd the moſt obdurate Heart; and when I ask'd him, why he did not acquaint your Ladyſhip with his Love, he would ſigh, with Arms a-croſs, as if his Heart would force its way through his Breaſt, and cry, Oh that's my Grief, my Friend, I cannot—dare not tell her! for ſhould I attempt it once, and meet her ſcorn, (for oh! thou know'ſt her Vow) I ſhou'd be for ever loſt.
Then ran o'er a thouſand Tales of Love, ſo ſoft, ſo moving, and how he priz'd you, that cannot be expreſs'd by any, except one, who loves like him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, if it be ſo—

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: If it be ſo! were your Ladyſhip to obſerve his diſtracted Throes, you'd pity him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: But why ſhould he not declare it to me?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: That's what I tell him, Madam;
Urging that your Ladyſhip—But mum! who have we here?

div.stage: Euter Viſcount, Philadelphia and Prudence.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Ha! Whiſpering! And ſo cloſe!
I like it not.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: The Viſcount! this is unlucky.
He looks diſturb'd! Good Sir, ſome other time we'll end this Diſcourſe. (to Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Ha! What are you, Sir? that thus dares to encroach upon my Territories, and invade my Right?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Nay, pray my Lord, be not diſpleas'd. This Gentleman, you muſt know, has a Law ſuit depending, and is come to entreat a Line of Commendation from me to my Lawyer.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Enough; I do believe all you can ſay. Ah! thoſe Eyes of yours! What Looks are there! they enflame my very Soul.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Ah, Prudence, how I long to be alone with him.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: I am impatient of this Delay, when ſhall we be married?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Pray moderate your Paſſion, Sir.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: What, you are afraid of that melancholy Gentleman, that ſtands ſo ſilently there.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Speak ſoftly, I am afraid he hears you▪ Sir.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: What care I if he does.

div.stage: Enter a Servant.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lord, the Dancers you ſpoke for, wait without.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Let 'em enter. Will you pleaſe to ſit, Ladies?

div.stage: A DANCE.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Prudence, go tell Mr. Lovemore, I'd ſpeak with him this Evening. (Exit Prudence.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: —you may take a Turn in the Garden. And, Sir, if you think it no Trouble, you may bear her Company. (To Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, moſt willingly. (Exit with Phil.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why are you ſo melancholy, my Lord?
