sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Nothing that's worth the naming. But if you'll walk into the next Room, I'll tell you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: My Lord, you are a Man of Honour, and I dare truſt my ſelf with you.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Madam, if I deſerve it not, may you always keep a Whip and a Bell, to ſcourge me from you like a Cur.

div.head: ACT IV.
div.stage: Enter Clodpole and Damaris: He gives her a Letter.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: YOU are a fine Spark, are you not, to diſcover all the Buſineſs, and let it come to my Maſter's Hearing?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why ay, that's true, as you ſay; but who wou'd have thought that he could have known it! But now to our own Buſineſs, Damaris—
Doſt thou not love me, Damaris?
Thou know'ſt I love thee with all my Heart.
Good lack! How it beats!—Odd, you may hear it thump all over the Houſe.
Damaris—How can'ſt thou be ſo hard-hearted?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pſhaw! Prithee leave fooling.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: One Kiſs, Damaris, to revive me.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Pray, Clodpole, be civil.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris!—Canſt thou not ſpare a little Bit afore-hand?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Of what, Fool?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why, of—Odd, you know well enough▪ What, I need not name it to thee.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I know nothing of the Matter.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ay, but you do. Why, I ask but a little tiney, tiney Bit. Do, prithee now do.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'll ſee you at the Devil firſt.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Do, Damaris—Spare but a Bit now; and bate me as much on the Wedding-Night.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: No, I thank you, good Clodpole: I have too often been ſnapt that way already. (Aſide.
But ſee—yonder comes my Lady and my Maſter— Step with me into the next Room, he muſt not ſee you.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Ay, any where, any where: Quickly, good Damaris. (Exit.

div.stage: Enter Barnaby Brittle and Mrs. Brittle.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I tell you again, that Marriage is a very ſacred Thing, and ought not to be profan'd at this Rate.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: What do you tell me of Marriage, I have other things to mind.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p:
Truly, I do believe as much; that's the trueſt Word you ever ſpoke: But I think you ought to mind what I ſay. Am I not your Husband? And
are not you bound in Duty by that Tye, to be obedient and juſt in all your Ways?

div.stage: Enter Lovemore on the other ſide bowing. She ſees him, and Curteſies to him.
div.p: What's that for? What, do you banter me?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Keep your Inſtructions for thoſe that want 'em, my Thoughts are other ways employ'd.

div.stage: (She Curteſies, Lovemore bows. Brittle ſees him not, and thinks ſhe does it in ſcorn to him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: What, you are practiſing your Airs againſt you meet your Gallant, are you? And trying how to behave your ſelf to him? But I ſhall ſpoil your Deſign, I ſhall. (He Bows, ſhe Curteſies again.
Leave off your Tricks with a Vengeance, and mind what I ſay to you. (Lovemore keeps Bowing to her.
Again, don't provoke me; I ſay, don't; if you do, you may chance to repent it. I ſay, that Marriage—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I know it, Dear; you need ſay no more.

div.stage: (She takes Brittle round the Neck, and beckons Lovemore, who comes and kiſſes her Hand over her Husband's Shoulders all the while.
div.p: You know I love you dearly, by this I do. (Kiſſes him.
Why will you not be ſatisfied? Had I the World to give, it cou'd not make me more happy than this Minute. (Lovemore ſtill kiſſes her Hand.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah diſſembling Crocodile?
What, now you think to wheedle me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Be ſatisfied with this: Hence forward, if you deſerve it, I give you my Heart for ever, which, till this Minute, I did not think to do.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah, would 'twere in your Power to keep your Word.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed I will, let that content you▪ and learn to merit that rich Jewel, which this Moment I put within your Power.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If thou would'ſt be thus kind always, how happy ſhould I be! But that's impoſſible! Would you but think ſometimes upon the Vow you made in Church, that ſolemn Vow of Marriage, 'twould put you in Mind of your Duty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: How can I think of any thing, when you will not give me leave ſo much as to peep abroad for Air? Do you think a Woman can ever be in a good Humour, that is lock'd up, and kept from what ſhe likes? But I'm reſolv'd to bear it no longer.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack! What's your Mind chang'd already? I thought 'twas too good to laſt long.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But hence-forward you ſhan't think to make a Fool of me at this rate. I'll find a way to get out, for all your Spies; and then look to't—I'll uſe you as you deſerve.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Tempt me no farther, I beſeech you; if you do, I ſhall uſe you as you deſerve. Patience! and I have need enough of it at this time.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I'm reſolv'd to encourage every Man, that makes Love to me. I'll kiſs and be wanton, ſince you provoke me to't. Love, and be belov'd—and not be ſubject to the naſty Humours of an old Jealous—I can't find a Name bad enough for thee.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Odd, I've a great Mind to ſpoil that handſome Face. The Devil tempts me ſtrangely: I muſt be gone; for if I ſtay, I ſhall certainly be provok'd to do her a Miſchief. (Runs off.

div.stage: Enter Damaris with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I waited till my Maſter was gone, to deliver you this Letter; Madam, Mr. Lovemore's Man is within, and waits for an Anſwer.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Give it me, Damaris, quickly.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I need not bid you read it, ſince you know from whom it comes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis extremely pretty, Damaris. I'll in, and write an Anſwer preſently. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: So ſhe has ſnapt the Bait at the firſt Angling; how ſhe'll get clear of the Hook, I know not. Ha! he's here himſelf!

div.stage: Enter Lovemore and Clodpole.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Pretty Mrs. Damaris, I'm glad to ſee you. Is your Lady within?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, writing an Anſwer to your Letter, I ſuppoſe. You ſee, I deliver'd it with Care.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, I underſtand you; there's for thy Pains.

div.stage: (Gives her Money, ſhe puts her Hand behind her, and takes it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir, by no means. But ſince you will have it ſo, pray command me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Can'ſt thou contrive to let me ſpeak with thy Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If you pleaſe, Sir, I'll ſhew you to her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Thou wilt oblige me for ever.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Hiſt! Damaris!—Odd, I ſhall have a rare Wife of her, if ſhe gets Money ſo faſt. Here's a piece of Gold got without the leaſt Trouble, as they ſay. But ſoftly!—Who have we here?

div.stage: Enter Brittle.
div.p: Oh! are you there, Mr. Babbler? You are a pretty Fellow indeed; you have made fine Work! You cannot be told a Secret, but you muſt tell the Husband preſently. You underſtand me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Who, I tell the Husband, Friend!

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Yes, you; but I'll ſee you hang'd before you ſhall get any thing more out of me. You have made fine Work! All's diſcover'd!—The Cuckold, her Husband, knows all the Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, but—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: You may as well hold your Tongue, for you ſhan't get a Word out of me.
No, no, I have found you out, I'faith.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: This Fellow may be uſeful to affirm it to her Father and Mother. I'll try to bribe him. (Aſide.
sp.stage: (Puts his Hand in his Pocket to give him Money.
sp.p: Why look you, Friend, I'm ſorry this Matter is—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Mum! You underſtand me.
I know what you'd ſay now, but 'twill not do. You'd have me to tell you what I know, but Mum!—Softly!—Not a Word. I'll warrant, you'd have me tell you what Anſwer ſhe gave to the Letter.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, Friend; but—

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly!—You ſhall get nothing out of me. You think I'll tell you now, that the Wife promis'd to meet him, and that they are together now in that Room; but I'm not ſuch a Fool. No, no, you'll tell the Husband again; you cannot be ſecret, and ſo good bye to you. You ſhall get nothing out of me. You underſtand me. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p:
I'm ſorry I can't make that uſe of him as I intended; but however, he has diſcover'd ſomething to me, that may do as well. He ſaid her Gallant is with her now; I'll liſten. (Goes to the Door.
Oh Sadneſs! 'tis but too true. Here's fine Doings. But I'll ſend for her Parents. Now they ſhall ſee who's in the wrong, and who's in the right. She can't ſcape me now, unleſs the Devil aſſiſt her; and ſee where they come in a lucky Hour.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter Pride and Lady P.
div.p: Father-in-law, you're welcome; and you, Madam. I'm glad you are come, I was juſt going to ſend for you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Why, what's the Matter, Son-in-law?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Now you ſee what a fine Daughter you have.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: What! more Complaints! What is the Reaſon of all this?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Do but hear me, and you ſhall know.
Here has been her Gallant, and—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Son-in-law, I'll not believe it. Will you never leave this fooling? We'll hear no more.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no; I knew you wou'd never believe a Word I ſay; but ſhe can be credited, becauſe ſhe's a Gentlewoman, forſooth. Now you ſhall ſee what a Gentlewoman I have got for a Wife. I have her faſt now, faſt in that Room with her Gallant, and that I hope will convince you.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: 'Tis falſe, thou baſe Villain. I know ſhe ſcorns to do ſo baſe a thing.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Pray now don't believe me, but walk in: If you find it not true, never mind any thing I ſay, as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Lead, Son-in law. If I find 'em together, by this good Sword they both ſhall die.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: But if 'tis not ſo, which I do believe 'tis only your Jealouſy again, look to your ſelf, Son-in-law, I'll ſuffer theſe Affronts no longer.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If they are not there now, I am a very Villain.
Come along—Softly— (They all go in.

div.stage: SCENE Changes to a Chamber, and diſcovers Lovemore, Mrs. Brittle, and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: You queſtion your own Power, when you miſtruſt my Honour, Madam. Such Charms can never want Force to allay all Thoughts of wronging ſo much Goodneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I do believe you to be a Man of Honour, and hope you will not wrong my good Opinion.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter, Lady Pride and Brittle, behind them. They grow enrag'd to ſee 'em together, and make Signs of Revenge. Sir Peter lays his Hand upon his Sword.
div.p: Therefore meet me this Evening at the Garden-Door about Nine, and there we'll diſcourſe farther: If I find what you ſay be real, perhaps I may be prevail'd upon to venture farther.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, you bleſs me! (Kiſſes her Hand.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Have a little Patience—
Let's draw nearer, and hear what they ſay.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh Madam! Madam! my Maſter, Sir Peter, and my Lady, are juſt behind you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Ha! undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What will become of me then?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Let me alone to bring it off.
Be not you ſurpriz'd at any thing I ſay, but ſeem to humour it.

I'll hear no more. (Seems to be angry with Lovemore. What do you tell me of your being amaz'd! Did you ever ſee any thing in me, that cou'd encourage you to believe I was that Woman you took me for? I'll warrant you thought, becauſe I ſeem'd to give you Encouragement before my Husband Yeſterday, when he had enrag'd me, that I was in earneſt?

div.stage: (They over-hear, ſeem angry, and to threaten Brittle, who pretends by Signs to excuſe himſelf.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: What mean you, Madam? (Confuſedly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But you will find your ſelf deceiv'd: For tho' my Husband gives me Provocations to uſe him at any rate, yet, Sir, I'd have you to know, I ſcorn Revenge; and will not be brib'd to ſtain my Honour, tho' all the Wealth of the whole World were laid at my Feet.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Do you hear that, Son-in-law?
sp.stage: They ſtill threaten, he looks ſneakingly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No, Sir, my honourable Parents brought me up with the ſtricteſt Care; taught me the nice Paths that lead to Everlaſting Fame and Glory: And he, who dares attempt to make me loſe my Way, deſerves to be us'd thus, thus, and thus, Sir.

div.stage: (Gets near Sir Peter, ſnatches his Cane, and runs at Lovemore, who gets behind Brittle. She beats Brittle unmercifully, while Lovemore gets off.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, Hold! Hold! What, will you murder me? (Brittle rubs his Shoulders.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Troth, Son-in-law, ſhe ſerv'd you right.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: You have not half what you deſerve;
And I cou'd find in my Heart to—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Let him alone: I'll correct him.
Son-in-law, You are a very impudent Fellow to uſe your Wife thus. What can you ſay for your ſelf? (Feels his Arms and Head.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Say for my ſelf! Why, I ſay, 'tis all a Trick—And a Contrivance to blind the Matter.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Is it not plain, you have wrong'd her? Do you not ſee ſhe is a virtuous and a good Wife?

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Too good for him, a Clown.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, well, I am over-reach'd, I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Son-in-law, I charge you let me hear no more of this. And inſtantly ask your Wife's Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: How, Sir!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Oh! let him alone; 'twill be to no purpoſe.
I'm a little out of Order.
Damaris, Lead me to my Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I ſay follow her, and ask her Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If I do, the Curſe of Cuckoldom fall upon me. (Runs out another way.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Ah, graceleſs Clown.
Come, Sir Peter, let's follow, and ſee how ſhe does.

div.stage: Enter Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, my Lady preſents her Service to your Ladyſhip and Sir Peter; and would deſire your good Company at a Ball the Viſcount treats her with.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Our humble Thanks to her Ladyſhip.
We will not fail to wait upon her.

div.stage: Enter Widow, meeting Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, Mr. Lovemore! I have expected you; I am glad you're come.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, Your Ladyſhip does me too much Honour.
Pray, Madam, when ſaw you Mr. Cuningham?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, Sir! He has told me all.

And now you talk of Mr. Cuningham—Prudence,
go find out my Niece, and have an Eye over her. (Exit Pru.
Well, Sir, I am ſorry you ſhou'd make your ſelf ſo great a Stranger to me. In ſuch Caſes I am not ungrateful. And where Love is real, there's a double Obligation.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ha! What does ſhe mean by Love and double Obligations? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I ſee indeed you ſeem to be in ſome Diſorder, that I ſhould know it; but had you let me known it ſooner, I ſhou'd perhaps have ſav'd you a great many Sighs and Heart-Akings, which you Baſhfulneſs has caus'd.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Sure ſhe's mad! [Aſide.] Madam—

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: And yet 'tis never too late to ſerve a Friend, and one that loves ſo dearly: Nor am I yet ſo far engag'd, but I can pity, nay make Return, when Love is ſincere, and ſo conſtant.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, you much amaze me!
Nor can I gheſs what you drive at!

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Ah, dear Sir! I know you are unwilling to let me know it: But ſhall I be ſincere in asking you one Queſtion?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Moſt freely; ſo it be not any thing that leads me farther into the dark.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Do you not love me, Sir?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Love you, Madam! Why truly I hate no body.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, but love me ſo, that it much diſturbs you, and that you fear I am engag'd to another.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: The Devil take me if I ever lov'd you, or can think what you wou'd be at.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Nay, I was told you would deny it,
But pray, Sir, tell me truly; for indeed, Sir, I am ſorry you ſhould ſuffer for my Sake. And ſhould you do otherwiſe than well, I vow it would be a Means of giving me diſquiet as long as I live.

sp.speaker: Loue.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, who told you this?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Your Friend Mr. Cuningham, who is much concern'd for you, Sir. And ſince you find it is diſcover'd, you need not be aſham'd to own the Truth.

div.stage: Enters Prudence, and liſtens.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, to deal freely with you, yov're abus'd; for hang me if ever I had a thought that way, nor do I love you, or ever can.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You're pleas'd to be merry, Sir; but I muſt tell you, I have obſerv'd it in your Looks; and ſince it is ſo, own it boldly to the World, and I promiſe you, I'll not be aſham'd, nor diſown mine. Come, come, Mr. Lovemore, you muſt not deny me that; for ſince I dare own it, why ſhould you think it ſtill amiſs?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well! Since all muſt out, prepare to hear me.

Mr. Cuningham has begun, and I muſt make an End. You muſt know, Madam, Mr. Cuningham loves you to that degree himſelf, that he's aſham'd, knowing how near a-kin he is to you, to let you know it, and ſo has form'd this Story upon me, the better to make for him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Mr. Cuningham a-kin to me, Sir!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Ay, Madam, your Nephew, your Brother's Son, whom he had in Paris by Madam D'Olone, but for ſome Reaſon he ſince has chang'd his Name.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Truly, Sir, you ſurprize me much! My Brother in Paris I heard had a Son, but what became of him I know not.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Madam, this Cuningham, my Friend, has the Misfortune (Misfortune I think it, and he thinks ſo too, becauſe he loves ſo dearly) to be related to you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'm ſorry, if he does love ſo well, that he ſhou'd be ſo near a-kin.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Madam, Mr. Cuningham is juſt come in.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll leave you, Madam, for I have a little Buſineſs that I muſt diſpatch—Beſides, 'twou'd not be convenient for me to interrupt what Diſputes you two may have.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant.
sp.stage: (As he goes out, meets Cuningham ent'ring.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Had you no body to put your Tricks on, but me?
But I think I have been even with you. (Exit Love.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What can he mean?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Mr. Cuningham, you do not deal like a Friend by me; you might have truſted me with a Secret of greater weight.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: I do not underſtand you, Madam!
What has he been ſaying to her? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You knew one Mrs. D'Olone, I ſuppoſe?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay now? (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Was your Brother then Mrs. D'Olone's Husband, Madam, and Mr. Cuningham's Father?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Who bid you ſpeak? Yes he was. What then?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, I begin to ſmoke it. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, but then Mr. Cuningham is your Nephew.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Indeed, I wiſh he were not; but ſince it is ſo, we muſt be ſatisfied with our Fate, Mr. Cuningham: Tho' you are much to blame, Sir, you did not let me know it ſooner before Matters went ſo far.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Madam, I confeſs my Fault, and do ask your Ladyſhip's Forgiveneſs.

div.stage: Enter Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Cuningham, ſince you are my Nephew, we may venture to embrace without a Bluſh.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Is Mr. Cuningam your Nephew, Madam?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Yes, Miſtreſs Pert, what then?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Then he's my Couſin, and I may embrace him too. (Runs and embraces each other.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, dear Couſin.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why how now ſaucy, impertinent Slut. How dare you take this Liberty?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why, is there any Harm in embracing one's own Couſin?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Get you in, Huſſy, and dare not to come but when I call you.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: He's none of your Couſin, Madam.
sp.stage: (Aſide to Phil. as ſhe goes out.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I know it. I met Mr. Lovemore laughing by the way, who told me all. Adieu, my dear Couſin

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: My charming Couſin, farewel.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll ſwear, Mr. Cuningham, you'll ſpoil that Girl.
Methinks you embrac'd her ſomething of the hardeſt. (Seems diſturb'd.

I call her Girl, and yet ſhe's near five and twenty—But as I was going to tell you, Sir, You muſt know, this Brother was not indeed my own Brother, but ſomething a kin afar off: He was my firſt Husband's firſt Wife's Brother, and no kin to me. But becauſe my Husband us'd to call him Brother, I would ſometimes do ſo too; and by this Means was thought, by thoſe that knew no other, to be my Brother.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Then he is not ſo near a-kin, but he may marry your Ladyſhip?

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh!— (Sighs.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why, truly, Mr. Cuningham—

div.stage: Enter Jeffrey in haſte.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir, your Lawyer bid me tell you, your Cauſe is juſt now coming on; and if you do not appear, you'll be non-ſuited.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Dear Sir, do not neglect your Buſineſs, nor let your being a-kin trouble you.
When next I ſee you.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! Wou'd I had never ſeen you, then I'd been happy; but where the Tye of Blood bars our Hopes, there's nothing but Deſpair in view. Madam, farewel.
Find ſome way to excuſe me, you Dog, or I'll cut your Throat. (To Jeffrey as he goes out.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay? (Aſide.
My Maſter has begun a Lie, and I muſt end it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Come hither, Jeffrey. Doſt think thy Maſter loves me ſo well as he ſays?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Faith, Madam, I believe he loves your Ladyſhip but too well! But Mr. Lovemore dies, unleſs you take pity on him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Doſt think he loves me better, than thy Maſter?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! They ought not to be nam'd together. Mr. Lovemore, poor Gentleman, is perfectly beſide himſelf about it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Didſt ever hear 'em talk about me?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: A thouſand times. Mr. Lovemore can talk of nothing elſe.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange he ſhould deny it to me.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: You muſt know, Madam, my Maſter was in Love elſe-where.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: If your Ladyſhip will have Patience to hear me out, you ſhall know the whole Story.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: With all my Heart, Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Why, you muſt know, Madam, my Maſter had the Misfortune to quarrel with a Gentleman, who urg'd him to fight; my Maſter kill'd him: Upon which he was forc'd to change his Habit and his Name—From Cuningham to Boutefeu. But thinking it not ſafe to ſtay here, fled; and in his Journey happen'd into a Viſcount's Caſtle, but the Viſcount was gone a Journey. However, this Viſcount had a very beautiful Siſter, that had the Command in her Brother's Abſence; ſhe entertain'd my Maſter very ſplendidly: At laſt he fell in love with her, and ſhe with him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Methinks ſhe was very forward, Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: She was ſo indeed, Madam; for before my Maſter left her, ſhe prov'd with Child.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How! with Child, and not married, Jeffrey!

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: My Maſter had promis'd her Marriage, Madam.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh, the impudent Creature! And thy Maſter was to blame, not to keep his Word, Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Not at all, Madam, when you have heard all. You muſt know, my Maſter grew jealous of one of the Servants, as indeed he had Reaſon: And one Day pretended to ride out, and he ſhou'd not return that Night, but left me to let him in, when the Servants were all a-bed, which I did. Going up to this Lady's Bed-Chamber, and not being expected that Night, found the Servant in Bed with her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Unheard of Impudence!
At firſt I was going to condemn thy Maſter, for deceiving a young Creature; but 'tis likely he was not the firſt, that had to do with her.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Very likely ſo, Madam. Next Day my Maſter was for packing up his Awls, and for going; ſhe cry'd, and urg'd his ſtay, and his Vows to marry her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: He had been more to blame to have done that.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: In the mean time the Viſcount return'd, found his Siſter in Tears, wou'd know the Reaſon, was told all. He ſwore, if ever he could get hold of him, he'd hang him at his Caſtle Gate, but my Maſter was got off ſafe. What it will come to, it they ſhould ever meet, I know not, but fear the Event.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A well invented Lye the Rogue has told. (Aſide. What was this Viſcount's Name?

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: The Viſcount Sans▪Terre, I think he was call'd.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: The Viſcount Sans-Terre!

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Why, he's in this Houſe.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: What, in this very Houſe?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: In this very Houſe; in the next Room.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Ah, my poor Maſter! he's but a dead Man, if he's found; for he'll certainly be hang'd.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here he comes. Hold your Peace!

div.stage: Enter Viſcount.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: My Lord, your Servant. I have a Queſtion to ask of you.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: What ſhall I do to make him underſtand? (Aſide.
Humour her in all ſhe ſays, my Lord.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Ask what thou wilt, I'll deny thee nothing.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You had a Siſter.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: I had ſo. Go on.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: And ſhe was unfortunately wrong'd by a baſe Fellow.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: What muſt I ſay next?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: 'Twas not well done to debauch her, and then to leave her; but Woe be to him, if your Lordſhip catch him.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: If ever I do find the Son of a Whore, I'll hang him at my Caſtle Gate.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: He was very much to blame indeed; but yet, all things conſider'd, he was not in all the Blame neither, counting what a Trick ſhe play'd him. He had reaſon to queſtion, whether the Child was his, or not.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: I'm quite at a Loſs. Oh! tell me what I muſt ſay next? (Faints into Jeffrey's Arms, who inſtructs him.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Take it in your Ear, my Lord. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Help, Prudence, my Lord faints.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, don't come too near, but give him Air. (Prudence and Jeffrey tell him what to ſay.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh! he recovers.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Give me a little Air. I beg your Pardon, I never hear my Siſter's Wrongs mention'd, but it puts me in Diſorder; but if ever I do light upon the Villain, Woe be to him.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'll try to get his Pardon. (Aſide.
My Lord, methinks her Crime being the greateſt, you might pardon him.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: What! Pardon him, that has deflower'd my Siſter, got her with Child of a Baſtard, and ſtain'd the Honour of our great Family! No, tho' all the World ſhould plead for him, I'll not forgive it; he dies.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Good, my Lord, for my Sake.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain, Lady. I'm told he's now in this Houſe, and has chang'd his Name. But if I find him— (Draws.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Oh hold, my Lord, I muſt ſave him. (Aſide. My Lord, I have but one Requeſt more.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: 'Twill be in vain: I'll have Revenge.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Tell him you'll marry him, Madam, and try what that will do. (Aſide to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Give me this Gentleman's Life, and I am content to be your Wife; otherwiſe—

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: 'Tis a hard Requeſt; but to ſhew how much I love you, upon that Condition I grant it.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Or, if you think ſit, you ſhall have my Niece Philadelphia, and with her I'll give you ten thouſand Pounds.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Do you think my Love ſo poor, that 'twill be brib'd? Nay, then I recal my Promiſe. He dies this Hour. (Draws and ſearches about.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, pray my Lord, forbear; my Lady did it but to try you! See, you fright her.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Well, my Lord, ſince it muſt be ſo, my Chaplain is within, I'm contented he ſhou'd make us one, make good but your Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: I confirm it here. (Kiſſes her.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: My Lord, the Dancers are ready to begin, and all the Company ſtay for you.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Let 'em enter, and begin when they pleaſe.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter Pride, Lady Pride, Lovemore, Mrs. Brittle, Cuningham and Philadelphia.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I rely upon your Promiſe.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Come, Gentlemen and Ladies, pray ſit.

div.stage: A DANCE.
After the Dance, Enter Barnaby Brittle, who runs after his Wife; they get between, he gets hold of her, and carries her off after Speaking.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Here's fine Doings! But I'll ſpoil your Sport. What! my Houſe is become a Muſic-houſe, is it? But, Gentlewoman, I have ſomething to ſay to you within.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: How now! What's the Meaning of this?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I ſay, my Wife—

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: What of your Wife?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Shall keep me Company, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: You Company!

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What's the matter with the Fellow? ha!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Come along, I ſay. What's here to do! Is not a Man's Wife his Wife? And may he not do what he will with her? (Carries her off.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: He's at his old Tricks again.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Come, let's in, and endeavour to appeaſe him, and then end our Mirth with a Banquet.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: We attend your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, do me the favour to lead my Siſter in.
Come, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Hold there, I will not part with you; I have two Hands, Madam, and can lead you both.

div.head: ACT V.
div.stage: Enter▪ Cuningham, Philadelphia and Jeffrey.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: FEar nothing; by what I could learn, by this time the old Lady is gone to her Chamber, or near being a▪bed.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Then we may have Time to talk more freely.

sp.speaker: Pbil.
sp.p: All is not ſo ſafe as you imagine. I fear another Storm before we yet can land. I know not by what means, but the Viſcount is diſcover'd to be a Counterfeit, which I have all along ſuſpected; but whether 'tis come to the Knowledge of my Aunt yet, I know not.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Therefore let's loſe no time, but tye that Knot, which joins our Hearts and Hands for ever: That once over, we have no farther need of the Viſcount.

div.stage: Enter Lovemore, and the Viſcount enrag'd, with Lights before 'em.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Never perſuade me; I'll not ſtay to be fool'd at this rate any longer.—Go lead, Sirrah.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What's the Matter now?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Matter! Why there's Matter enough in hand. We are all undone; the Match is broke off again, and you are like to loſe your Miſtreſs. The Widow will not conſent you ſhall marry her Niece; upon which, the Viſcount enrag'd, (as indeed he has Cauſe) is reſolv'd to ſtay no longer.
What 'twill come to, I know not.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: This is moſt unlucky. What's to be thought on next?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I left Prudence reaſoning the Caſe with her; what will be the Concluſion, is moſt uncertain. Oh! here ſhe comes.

div.stage: Enter Prudence.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Oh, Madam! the ſaddeſt News!

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why? What's the Matter?

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: All the Buſineſs is over. Poor Mr. Cuningham—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Ha! What of him? Speak.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: After a thouſand Arguments, which I us'd to perſuade her, ſhe has at laſt reſolv'd—I can't ſpeak it.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: On what? Prithee out with it.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Why, to marry the Viſcount her ſelf, and give you and your ten thouſand Pounds to Mr. Cuningham.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh the bleſs'd News! What ſay you now, Madam?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I'll ſwear I was in a Fright at firſt.
But art thou ſure ſhe'll hold in this Mind?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: For fear of the worſt, get all things ready, and let it be done this Moment.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: Here ſhe comes. Seem concern'd to part with her, Sir, and try how ſhe ſtands reſolv'd.

div.stage: Enter Widow.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: And muſt I then loſe her, Prudence!
Oh, the racking Thought! Hard! Hard! Decree of Fate! To part with all I hold moſt dear! I cannot bear it. (Walks about.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Yes, Mr. Cuningham, our Stars will have it ſo.

Tis hard indeed to part: But ſince there is no way left to ſave your Life, (which more than all the World I prize) but this only, I have at laſt reſolv'd (tho' much againſt my Will) to give my ſelf to the Viſcount.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Oh! do not name it, Madam, the very Thought is worſe, than Death.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: I'm ſorry we are ſo near a kin, but that's not the chief Reaſon; your Vow to marry another, and yet when I conſider ſhe was falſe, and had to do with more, than one, and that the Child might as well not be yours, I think you were in the right to part: So I am content (ſince my Hopes are loſt) that you ſhou'd marry with my Niece. But believe me, you do not know how much I'm troubled▪ to ſee another take what I ſo much deſir'd. But we muſt endeavour to be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Never! Never! for ſince I loſe you, farewel to Love and Joy: The reſt of Life I'll waſte in Sorrow.

div.stage: Enter Clodpole, whiſpers Lovemore.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Softly! Damaris bad me tell you, that her Miſtreſs ſtays for you at the Garden Door.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, very well. I'll go this Moment.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: But what will you do to recal the Viſcount, Madam, who left the Houſe in Anger, nor told any one what his Deſigns were?

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I heard him bid the Link-boy lead to the Devil Tavern. If you pleaſe, thither we'll go, and conclude upon the Matter. A Glaſs or two of Wine may fetch him about again.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Truly, Mr. Lovemore, I'm much oblig'd to you, and ſhall endeavour to return your friendly Advice. I hope we ſhall live as loving Neighbours ought, but now we loſe time. The Viſcount may perhaps be gone, ſhould we ſtay longer.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll but give ſome Directions to my Man, and • e there almoſt as ſoon as you.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: You will oblige us, Sir.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: 'Tis main dark, nothing to be ſeen but the Sky and Stars. What can this Darkneſs portend! The Almanicks this Year ſay, That many things will be huddled in the dark.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Why, thou art an Aſtrologer, Clodpole, thou talk'ſt ſo learnedly.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Why, truly I am but a Piece of one; but had I been a great Schollard, I believe I ſhou'd have thought on things, that never had been thought on before.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Very likely, truly. But hark! What Noiſe is that? There's Brittle's Houſe; may be ſhe is coming out.

div.stage: Enter Mrs. Brittle and Damaris.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Softly Damaris, juſt ſhut the Door, we'll not be far from it.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Is your Husband faſt, Madam?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I would not ſtir till I ſaw him aſleep; he's ſnoring like one that's drunk.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That's her Voice. Madam, where are you?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: There they are, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: You find, Sir, I am as good as my Word. I hope you are a Man of Honour, as you ſay; yet were it to do again, I ſhould hardly venture ſuch another bold Attempt.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Fear nothing, Madam. Your Perſon and your Honour both are ſafe, whilſt I am your Guard. Can none over hear us?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: All the Family, but Damaris and I, are gone to Bed; nor dare we be long from thence, leſt my Husband ſhould wake, and miſs me.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Talk not of parting e'er we well are met; that were unkind, Madam.
If you pleaſe, Madam, to walk a little farther this way, here's a Place more private, than the reſt, and will beſt befit our Diſcourſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I'll not queſtion your Honour any more, but truſt my ſelf with you; as you behave your ſelf now, expect a greater Liberty another time.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: I'll warrant you: This way, my Charmer.

div.stage: (He leads her out; ſhe takes hold of Damaris, who follows.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Damaris!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I'm here, Madam.
sp.stage: (Clodpole feels with his Stick for Damaris.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris!—Softly!—Damaris!—Damaris!

div.stage: Enter Brittle, groping in the dark in a Cap and a Night-Gown.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Where can ſhe be gone at this time of Night? I heard her ſteal down; I'll liſten.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris, Where art thou, Damaris!—Odd, 'tis main dark.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Who have we here? Here's ſomething more than ordinary. But I'll draw nearer.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris, Where art thou?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Here. (In a low Voice: Clodpole feels him with his Stick, thinks 'tis Damaris.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Oh! art thou there?

Well, Damaris, muſt not thee and I follow the Example of thy Miſtreſs, and my Maſter? I'll warrant they'll be hugeous kind to one another; for my Maſter, you muſt know, has a mighty Love for her, and ſo belike ſhe has for him; or elſe ſhe wou'd ne'er a left her Husband a bed to a come to him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh horrid! 'tis ſo. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: How he ſnores now, if a Body were to hear him! Poor Cuckold! He little dreams what his Wife and my Maſter are doing. Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh! this is my Country Chap again. (Aſide.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Poor Cuckold, 'tis good enough for him. For as they ſay, he uſes her mighty ill. But, Damaris, muſt thee and I part thus? One little Bit to ſtay my Stomach, Damaris: 'Tis fit, we ſhou'd follow our Leaders. (Gues to Kiſs.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I can hold no longer. Who goes there?

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Odd ſo! Oh! Oh! Who's that? Oh!

div.stage: Puts his Stick a-croſs, and in running out-ſtops againſt the Scenes; at laſt gets off.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: So—He's gone. Here's a Diſcovery at laſt! Here's a fine Virtuous Wife for you! But now all will out in ſpite of her. I'll ſend inſtantly for her Parents; they ſhall ſee now who's in the right. Oh bleſs us! What, make her Husband a Cuckold! Oh! Monſtrous! (Goes to the Door, and calls.
Jeremy! the Varlet's a▪ſleep, I'll warrant. Jeremy, I ſay.
(Jer. above) Do you call, Sir?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Yes, I do call. Come down quickly, I muſt ſend you to my Father-in-law's.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: I come, Sir. (Puts a Rope out, and ſlides down.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Make haſte, Sirrah. How long you are coming. Ah! Villain!

div.stage: (Jeremy treads upon his Toes, and gets from him.
div.p: You have trod upon my Corns, and lam'd me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: I dare not, Sir; you'll beat me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! 'tis well I ſtand in need of thee.

Run to my Father and Mother-in-Law, and tell 'em, I intreat to ſpeak with 'em this Moment; tell 'em I'll
never trouble 'em again as long as I live; beg 'em by all means to come.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes, Sir. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Now they ſhall ſee what a Daughter they have.
Now I ſhall ſure convince 'em of their Error!
But I hear ſome body coming!
May be I ſhall make a farther Diſcovery. (Stands aſide.

div.stage: Enter Lovemore, Mrs. Brittle, Damaris, and Clodpole.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Nay, Sir, I've ſtay'd long enough for one time: Should my Husband wake, and miſs me, I were undone.
I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Stay one Minute longer, I beſeech you, Madam.
I have not told you yet—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No more, Sir, if you love me. Farewel.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, ſtay! How can you go, and leave me ſo ſoon?

You will have time enough to lie by that dull, ſtupid Clod, your Husband, e'er the Morning: Methinks I grudge him the leaſt Look of you, ſince he knows not how to value ſo rich a Jewel. Let him live, and pore o'er his Bags, his Droſs, and worldly Gains, whilſt we know better how to waſte our youthful Hours in ſofteſt Kiſſes, and everlaſting Joys.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, blaſting Sound! But I have heard enough.
Now to my Poſt. (Exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Good Night, Sir: Now I muſt be gone.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: When ſhall I be thus bleſs'd again?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: To Morrow I'll ſend for you; and, if poſſible, appoint another Meeting.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Till then, ten thouſand Angels wait on thee. One Kiſs e'er we part. (Kiſſes her. Oh, I could dwell for ever on thy Lips!
Sure, there's Enchantment on 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Farewel!

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Adieu, my lovely Charmer. (Exit with Clod.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Now, Damaris, let's ſteal in: Softly! Softly!

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: O Lord, Madam! We are undone!
The Door is faſt ſince we have been out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: What ſhall we do now, Damaris?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: I wiſh my Maſter has not been down.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Let's call Jeremy ſoftly.

sp.speaker: Both.
sp.p: Jeremy! Jeremy!

div.stage: (They both call up to the Window in a ſoft Tone.
Brittle at the Window above.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Jeremy! Jeremy! (In their Tone.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, my Maſter!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Loſt! Undone for ever!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah! Ha! my ſweet Lady! Have I caught you at laſt!
Jeremy! Jeremy!
Where has your ſweet Ladyſhip been, I pray, that you are ſo afraid of being diſcover'd? Come, I know you have a Lie in readineſs: Let's have it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: No where but juſt with Damaris, to take a little of the freſh Air; that's all, indeed, ſweet Husband.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: To take the freſh Air, quotha!
Ah, I rather believe 'twas to take a Heat, you Witch you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, Husband, let the Door be open'd?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No: You ſhall ſtay there till your Parents come.
I have ſent for them: They ſhall ſee what Hours you keep. And know of your Gallant you juſt parted from, your vigorous Lover.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Madam, he over-heard all,
And we are undone. (Aſide to her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: What, have you no Excuſe ready?
No Invention? You and your wicked Inſtrument there, that ſtands like the Serpent at Eve's Elbow, to tempt her to Sin.
What, is your Prompter to Wickedneſs dumb?
I'd fain hear how you intend to excuſe it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I don't go about to excuſe it, Husband—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No; That's becauſe you don't know how.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I do confeſs, I have been to meet a Gentleman, but not alone; Damaris was with me. And ſure there was no Crime in a little harmleſs Chat.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No, no, not in the leaſt; making me a Cuckold is no harm at all.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, Husband, let me in, and I'll never do the like again, as long as I live; but you ſhall hence-forward find me the moſt dutiful Wife, that you could wiſh for. Pray, Husband, truſt me but this once.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Do not diſgrace me to my Parents, by expoſing me at this unſeaſonable Hour, in which I do confeſs I am much to blame—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh! Do you ſo?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: But forgive me now, I'll never do it again.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Hang them that believes you, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I am ſure I never injur'd you in all my Life; but am as innocent as the Child unborn, from doing the Ill, which you ſuſpect.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: It may be ſo: 'Twas not your Fault then.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, dear Husband, believe me, and let me in.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: On my Knees I ask your Pardon, do but open the Door.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: If you let me in this time, 'twill work upon me more, than all the Liberty in the World cou'd do beſide.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I care not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Indeed, Husband, I love you dearly, and love you only: How can you then be ſo cruel to refuſe me?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah, cunning Crocodile?
Now you are caught, 'tis dear Husband, ſweet Husband, 'tis only you I love: But at another time, 'tis good for nothing old Fool. No, no, I know you well enough, and ſo ſhall your Parents now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Pray, Husband, let the Door be open'd▪

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Try me but this once.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I tell you, no.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Not once more?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: No.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: If you provoke me, I may deſpair, grow deſperate, and do a Deed, which you may repent.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Good lack! What will your ſweet Ladyſhip do?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I'll kill my ſelf with this Knife here.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Oh, very well!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Nay, 'twill not be ſo well as you imagine neither. Every body knows how ill we have liv'd, and when I'm dead, People will think you murder'd me.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ay!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Therefore I'll kill my ſelf, to have my Death reveng'd upon you.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Odd, I'll truſt to that.
Beſides, killing ones ſelf has been a great while out of faſhion. But why don't you diſpatch? Methinks you are long about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt,
sp.p: You may believe me, for I'll certainly do it, if you perſiſt.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Odd, I'll venture it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Beſides, when I am dead, my Ghoſt ſhall haunt you.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ah, if I cou'd but once get rid of your Perſon here, I ſhould not fear your Ghoſt hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Have you no Pity left?
I am juſt going to do it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And yet you are long about it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Since nothing but my Death can ſatisfy you—
There and there!

div.stage: (Pretends to ſtab her ſelf with her Fan, and ſalls.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Oh, ſhe has don't! She has don't!
Oh cruel, barbarous Monſter, to make her kill her ſelf!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Now, Damaris, you find too late I did not jeſt—
I know thou'lt ſee my Death reveng'd upon my cruel Husband, who has accus'd me falſly; for I affirm with my dying Breath, I never wrong'd him. Farewel!
Death beckons me into a dark and gloomy Vale, where I muſt follow.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: She's gone! She's gone!
Oh, thou worſe than Savage! To murder ſo ſweet a Lady, ſo innocent and ſo good: Nay, I'll ſwear you did it. (Cries over her.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I hear no Noiſe! (Looks frighten'd. Is't poſſible the Devil ſhou'd be ſo great with her, that ſhe cou'd kill her ſelf to be reveng'd on me!
But I'll light a Candle, and go ſee.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Now, Damaris, ſtand cloſe in this Corner:
Cloſe, Cloſe. (They ſtand aſide.

div.stage: Enter Brittle with a Light; they ſlip by him, go in, and lock the Door: He looks about.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha! I thought indeed how well ſhe'd do it: Here's none of her! She made me believe ſhe kill'd her ſelf, and the mean while ran away. Well, e'en let her go; I ſhall have this Satisfaction, her Parents ſhall be Witneſs of her Hours. I'll in, and wait their coming.

div.stage: (Goes to the Door, and finds it lock'd. Knocks.
Mrs. Brittle and Damaris above at the Window, where he was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Away, you idle Sot; is this a time of Night for an honeſt Man to come home in?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: Go, go, you may be aſham'd!

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, have you the Impudence—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: How many Nights am I forc'd to ſit up to wait for his coming in? And he tells the World, 'tis I am to blame. But now it ſhall be ſeen who's to blame, and who not. My Father and Mother are coming, they ſhall ſee what Hours you keep—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I confeſs, I ſtand amaz'd at this Impudence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: They ſhall know all.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, have you the Face to deny—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Go, go, I'll hear none of your impudent Excuſes; you are drunk, you Sot, you Swine. But here comes my honourable Father and Mother.

div.stage: Enter Sir Peter and Lady Pride.
div.p: I'm glad you are come to be Witneſs of what I ſtill ſuffer, by this ungrateful Uſage of a cruel Husband. You ſee what Hours he keeps; every Night at the Tavern roaring with his Companions, whilſt I am forc'd to ſit at home alone, waiting for his coming; and when he does come, he ſtrait raves and abuſes me at ſuch a rate, that I am not able to endure it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why, was there ever ſuch Impudence!
I wiſh this Candle were in my Belly, if—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I know what he'll ſay now, if you'll believe him; he'll tell you, that I am ſtill in the wrong, and 'tis I that have been out at this late Hour, and as for his part, he has been within all this Evening, and knows nothing of all this Matter, not he: But I'll leave your ſelves to judge, if this is an Hour for an honeſt Husband to come home at.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Why then may I never—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: You ſee he's ſo drunk, he can hardly ſtand.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Faugh!—I ſmell him hither.
He ſtinks of Liquors and Tobacco like a Tarpaulin, that has not been ſober whilſt his Twelve-Months Pay wou'd laſt.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I tell you, that I am not drunk, nor have I been out of my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Stand farther off, I cannot bear the Scent of a Drunkard.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: I told you he wou'd deny it.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: I ſay, that 'tis ſhe that has been out juſt now, and with her Gallant, and therefore I ſent for you; and that I have not been out of my Doors.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Do you hear him? But Damaris can juſtify, I have not ſet my Foot over the Threſhold ſince Day-light.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If ſhe has, never believe me more.
I can aſſure your Honours 'tis true; for I have not been out of her Company ſince he went out to the Tavern.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Therefore I do beſeech you, good Father and Mother, to revenge my Cauſe, for I am not able to endure it any longer: If I do, you'll never ſee me alive another Week.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: 'Tis a ſtrange thing, that ſhe muſt be believed, and I not.
I tell you—

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Stand farther off.
Faugh! What a Smell there's about him.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well then; I'll ſtand farther off, if you will but hear me ſpeak. (Goes backward. I ſhall ſay nothing but the Truth, and what I can prove.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Again at your Proofs, and your idle Jealouſies!

Be dumb, Coxcomb; it were a good deed to break your Head, for ſending thus for us out of our Beds, and making Fools of us ſtill. If you ever dare to do the like again, we'll find a Means to handle you—
If there be no Law (but cutting of Throats) to revenge theſe Affronts—I ſay no more—But remember you are warn'd.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: If you wou'd but let me tell why I ſent for you—

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: We have heard and ſeen too much already.
Therefore dare not to ſpeak a Word more.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: And is this all his Puniſhment?

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: No; Come down, and he ſhall ask your Pardon. 'Tis the leaſt he can do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: 'Twill be to no purpoſe; when your Backs are turn'd, he'll be as bad again.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: I ſay no more Diſputes, but do as I command. (They come down from the Window.
Now, Son-in-law, kneel down, and ask your Wife Forgiveneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Shall I forgive him; no, I deſire to be divorc'd.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Come, Daughter, I ſay you muſt pardon him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Well, Madam, I'll endeavour to obey you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Why don't you kneel, and do as I command?

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Well, I find there's no Remedy, ſhe has over-reach'd me again, and I muſt ſubmit: But I am reſolv'd I'll get rid of this Nooze, tho' I tuck my ſelf up in another.
sp.stage: (Sir Peter makes him kneel to his Wife.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Come, ſay after me. Madam, I ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Madam, I ask your Pardon.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: For the Folly I have committed—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: For the Folly I have committed in marrying you.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: In my wild Suſpicions.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: In my wild Suſpicions.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: Which I do declare were utterly falſe.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Which I do declare were utterly falſe.

sp.speaker: Sir Peter.
sp.p: And that I ſwear never to do the like again.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: And that I ſwear never to do the like again, if I were once unmarried.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Here—Kiſs the Book. (Gives her Hand. But if ever you do't again—
You ſee 'tis to no purpoſe to turn Hagard; if you do, I'll tame you. (Aſide to him.

sp.speaker: Lady.
sp.p: Look if the Noiſe has not brought all the Company hither.

div.stage: Enter Viſcount, Widow, Lovemore, Cuningam, Philadelphia, Prudence, Clodpole, and Jeffrey, with Lights before 'em.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Your Servant, Sir Peter. Sir, I hope you will not take it ill; we ſaw a Light in your Houſe, and ſo made bold: We are reſolv'd to ſpend an Hour or two in Mirth, and hope you will all join with us.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: Your Ladyſhip I know will pardon it upon this Occaſion. (To Lady Pride.

sp.speaker: Lady Pride.
sp.p: Is your Ladyſhip marry'd? May we give you Joy?

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: My Niece and Mr. Cuningham are.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Give you Joy then.

sp.speaker: Cun. and Phil.
sp.p: We thank you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now, Sir, ſince our Hands are join'd, and all is reconcil'd, I have a Boon to ask.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Whate'er it be, conclude it done.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I have obſerv'd ſome Sparks of Love between Jeffrey and Prudence; and I believe they wou'd be glad to follow our Example.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: What ſay'ſt thou, Jeffrey? If thou haſt a Mind to marry, ſpeak freely.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: Sir, I have debated much about the Matter, and am at laſt reſolv'd to venture.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: Then if you, Madam, give your Conſent, and Prudence be willing, we'll put 'em together.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: With all my Heart; Prudence has been always a good Servant, I'll ſay that for her.

sp.speaker: Jeff.
sp.p: There's my Hand then; the reſt of my Body ſhall be forth coming.

sp.speaker: Pru.
sp.p: A Match.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Then let me ſpeak. Clodpole loves Damaris, and I believe wou'd be glad to make up the Chorus; now if Mrs. Brittle pleaſe to part with her—

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: You ſhall have my Conſent with all my Heart; and I'll give a Sum of Money to be rid of her.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: And I'll give Clodpole ſomething to ſet him up in a little Farm in the Country.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Damaris!—Doſt hear that?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: What ſay you, Damaris?

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: If I thought he'd make a good Husband, and not be jealous—

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: That I dare anſwer for him.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: Well, then 'tis agreed, and there's my Hand.

sp.speaker: Dam.
sp.p: For better for worſe.

sp.speaker: Clod.
sp.p: To have and to hold; a Tenement for Life.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: And now all things being thus happily concluded—

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: No, Mr. Cuningham, not while your Friend is unprovided. Methinks 'twere pity he ſhou'd be no Actor in this Comedy.

sp.speaker: Love.
sp.p: Oh, Madam, my Thoughts are not yet fix'd ſo much upon any Object, but the next I encounter can retrieve the paſt.

sp.speaker: Cun.
sp.p: My Friend never wants a Miſtreſs (I'll ſay that for him) in any Place, if he has but an Opportunity, which he ſeldom wants. I have often wonder'd at his Luck.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Britt.
sp.p: Say you ſo? I find he makes it his Buſineſs to enſnare and deceive Women at this rate.

I'm glad I know it in time, whilſt I have Power to make my Retreat. I had like to have been finely caught. Well, Husband, ſeeing ſo many join'd in Happineſs, if you'll promiſe never to be jealous, I'll promiſe from this Moment never to give you Cauſe, and endeavour to make you as happy as I can.

sp.speaker: Britt.
sp.p: Wou'd you'd give me Cauſe once to believe you.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: Well then, if you are all agreed, the Parſon that marry'd Mr. Cuningham is but juſt by; e'en ſend for him, and let him end the Work he has begun.
For my part, I intend to put off mine for ſome time longer.

sp.speaker: Widow.
sp.p: How! My Lord! Have you ſerv'd me thus? Did I forſake all for you, and do you pretend to—

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: No Words now, 'twill ſpoil Company; another time we'll diſcourſe it farther. Come, let's have a Dance, and then to Bed.

sp.speaker: Omn.
sp.p: With all our Hearts.

div.stage: A DANCE.

sp.speaker: Viſc.
sp.p: 'Tis well: So now, you that are ready to taſte the Sweets of Matrimony, fall to; for my part, I have no great Stomach to it yet.
sp.l: And none I hope will blame me if I tarry,
Since thoſe that wed in haſte, as faſt miſcarry.
